{"uri": "2024-06-380050044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/celtics-news-jayson-tatum-jaylen-brown-eye-opening-kyrie-irving-praise-nba-finals", "title": "Celtics' Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown get eye-opening Kyrie Irving praise ahead of NBA Finals", "body": "When the 2024 NBA Finals begin on Thursday, there will be no love lost between the Boston Celtics and the Dallas Mavericks. These two organizations have a chance to win a championship, and there are various storylines that tie into what could become a historic matchup. Perhaps the greatest headline revolves around Kyrie Irving going up against his former team. As many would expect, the city of Boston won't be kind to Kyrie, nor will they embrace him back once this series tips off. But for Irving, this championship series against Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, and the Celtics is sort of like a reunion.\n\nIrving has never been the type of person to hold grudges. He especially has no ill feelings towards Tatum or Brown, who were both young players in Boston during Kyrie's two seasons with the team. When questioned about what it feels like going up against his former teammates in the NBA Finals during media day on Wednesday, Irving made it clear that he's proud of everything Tatum and Brown have achieved.\n\n\"I'm excited,\" Irving told reporters at media day. \"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them. I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best. They have a great team over there, led by a great coach. So we're going to be in for a great series, hard, tough\n\nseries.\n\n\"They're going to give us their best. I know they're not going to slow down when they see me. They're going to come at me even more.\"\n\nIrving, Tatum, and Brown shared the court with one another in Boston during the 2017-18 and 2018-19 seasons. These three stars were able to advance to the 2018 Eastern Conference Finals with one another, where they lost in seven games to the Cleveland Cavaliers.\n\nDespite all the backlash he has received in his career from Boston, Irving has not let that impact his relationship with either Tatum or Brown. Even though these two stars are Irving's enemies ahead of the NBA Finals, he is still proud of what they have been able to accomplish, given the types of players Tatum and Brown were earlier in their careers when Kyrie was their teammate.\n\nKyrie Irving ready for Boston return in NBA Finals\n\nThe Mavericks roll into the NBA Finals with Irving on a hot streak. He recently had 36 points and five assists in the team's Game 5 victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves in the Western Conference Finals, marking his third 30-point performance in his last five games.\n\nIrving has won a championship before, and he knows the type of mentality it takes to achieve greatness on the NBA's biggest stage. Fans and the environment are always factors in how games play out, but Kyrie isn't about to let all of the outside noise get in the way of his ultimate goal.\n\n\"You just got to breathe through it. To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions, what they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is,\" Irving explained. \"Don't overthink it. Been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness. It could all be turned into a strength. There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball. The fans are going to say what they're going to say.\n\n\"I appreciate them and their relationship they have to the game, but it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nThis NBA Finals series in particular is going to be heavily focused on the players and the matchups that will exist. Not only do the Mavericks present Luka Doncic and Irving from their side of things, but the Celtics have been the best team in the league all season.\n\nIn addition to Tatum and Brown, they have other star-quality players like Derrick White, Jrue Holiday, and Kristaps Porzingis. Boston is an experienced, veteran team that has had the NBA Finals circled on their calendars before the season even began. While many did not expect Dallas to be in this spot, Irving has known all along that this is where the Mavericks belonged. Now, it is time for Kyrie to prove to everyone that the Mavs are the best team in the NBA.\n\n\"This is what I've been preparing for since last summer or when our season ended last year. Once Kyrie Irving took the podium, the first question he received was about his former teammate LeBron James.\n\n\"Is that the first question?\" Kyrie Irving chuckled. \"Oh, God, I love it. Got to love this, man.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Celtics' Jrue Holiday Gets Brutally Honest About Guarding Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving\n\nJames gave high praise to Irving on his \"Mind The Game\" podcast, calling him a \"wizard\" and that he's \"so f*****g mad that I am not his running mate anymore.\" He's probably feeling a little disappointed that his Lakers lost in the first round while Irving is about to play in the NBA Finals.\n\nIrving saw the comments and when asked about his thoughts, he responded \" I mean, I have a great reaction. It's appreciated. There's a lot of gratitude there, as well. I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now. Definitely miss him. Playing out there, just making things easier, being able to run up and down the floor, just throw the ball to somebody like that, throw it in the air, as athletic as they come... Shout-out to LeBron for that. Knows how to stir up a media storm, get everybody in here talking about us. Yeah, I'm looking forward to the future and getting this series started now.\"\n\nBoth players have come a long way since Irving was traded to the Boston Celtics in 2017. James departed for the Los Angeles Lakers in the 2018 offseason, winning a championship in the 2020 Bubble, and became the NBA's all-time leading scorer, passing the great Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. Irving, meanwhile, signed with the Brooklyn Nets after two seasons in Boston and wore out his welcome in Brooklyn. After three and a half seasons there, he was traded to Dallas at the 2023 trade deadline, where is now thriving alongside Luka Doncic.\n\nAt the time Irving was traded away from Cleveland, he wanted to prove he could lead a team without being in the shadow of LeBron James. Now that he's grown and matured and can see things from a different perspective, it had to have been thrilling to play with one of the greatest players this game has ever seen at the peak of his powers, winning a championship together in 2016. {"uri": "8165131338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:35:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:35:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:34:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/basketball/nba/dallas-mavericks/2024/06/06/6661e97eca47414b7d8b45a0.html", "title": "Kyrie Irving confirms the reason he misses sharing a team with LeBron James", "body": "NBA. Lebron James admits he is still \"F**king mad\" at Kyrie Irving ahead of the NBA Finals\n\nDuring a recent podcast with J.J. Reddick, LeBron James said Kyrie Irving is the most gifted player he has ever seen. Leading up to the NBA finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, Kyrie was asked about those comments coming from his former teammate at the Cleveland Cavaliers. Irving clearly seemed like he would've loved to play alongside LeBron James again and even admitted he misses the Lakers star. Keep in mind that Irving was a potential option to play for the Lakers last year before he ultimately decided to play alongside Luka Doncic at the Dallas Mavericks. Kyrie went on a long response when asked about James' recent praise directed towards him.\n\nIrving said: \"I appreciatd his sentiments. Obviously, I'm in a different age, different place in my life. So is he. I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish,\" Irving said. \"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now. Definitely miss him. Man, when he says comments like that, I think back to us having those moments where we're down in a series, up in a series, we're really demanding greatness from each other. Off the court, our families meshing well. ... I definitely think about those times.\"\n\nFortunately for Kyrie Irving, he is not alone at the Dallas Mavericks. In fact, he is playing this series alongside one of the young talents with the most unreal proyection in the entire league. Luka Doncic arrived at the NBA without realizing the tremendous impact he would have so early in his career. Irving is no longer the young buck he once was when the Cavaliers were dominant in the Eastern Conference. Today, Irving is a much more experienced player who is helping the Mavs tremendously with his still intact ball handling skills. There's a lot of gratitude there, as well.\"\n\nJames said he missed playing with Irving during their NBA Finals preview in his \"Mind the Game\" podcast with ESPN analyst JJ Redick.\n\n\"I will call Kyrie the wizard all the time,\" James said when Redick asked him about Irving. \"There was nothing on the basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do. I'm playing like so happy and so proud and to watch him and continue his growth and whatever the case and at the same time I'm so [expletive] mad at the same time that I am not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nThe feeling is mutual.\n\n\"Definitely miss him,\" Irving said. \"Playing out there, just making things easier, being able to run up and down the floor, just throw the ball to somebody like that, throw it in the air, as athletic as they come.\n\nYeah, just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table. His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I'm appreciative for the rest of my life.\"\n\nIrving and James went to three straight NBA Finals in Cleveland and won one via historic fashion -- the first 3-1 comeback in finals history -- in 2016 which ended the city's title drought.\n\nBut their relationship quickly disintegrated after that as Irving demanded a trade to lead his own team and step out of James' shadows.\n\nIrving failed in Boston then he teamed up with Kevin Durant in Brooklyn which also ended in a disappointment.\n\nIrving admitted he had misgivings in his past relationship with James.\n\n\"Obviously, I'm in a different age, a different place in my life,\" Irving said. \"So is he. I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\n\n\"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\"\n\nNow 32, Irving found his redemption with the Mavericks after an ugly start -- failing to qualify for the postseason.\n\nJames' compliment serves as motivation for Irving, who also gleans on his experience playing with James in the Finals to help the Mavericks break through with Luka Doncic.\n\n\"Man, when [James] says comments like that, I think back to us having those moments where we're down in a series, up in a series, we're really demanding greatness from each other,\" Irving said. \"Off the court, our families meshing well.\n\nI definitely think about those times. Now we're here in the present where we're able to reflect but also now I'm at this stage, able to use some of the formulas that I was taught from him, some of the great teachers that have come before me. I feel like I've been built for this moment because I've gone through some of the things I've gone through in my past with some of the guys that have transcended the game.\"\n\nThe Celtics, who are -244 favorites to win the series opener per lucky block, one of the best crypto casinos with sportsbook, would be the biggest challenge for Irving and Doncic's growing partnership.\n\nTheir spectacular play in the playoff prompted TNT's Stan Van Gundy to call them \"arguably the best offensive backcourt in NBA history\" as the Mavericks dynamic duo enter the finals with a combined average of 51.0 points in their first playoff run together.\n\n\"Luka and Kyrie are the 2nd starting backcourt since 1970-71 to enter the NBA Finals averaging a combined 50+ PPG in the postseason, joining Clyde Drexler and Terry Porter in 1992!\" NBA tweeted on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nBut Irving is unfazed especially with the Boston crowd certain to heckle him all game long.\n\n\"I've experienced Boston twofold: my first few years being in the NBA playing for the Cavs, then coming here to Boston, then being right down the street in Brooklyn, now being here in the Finals playing against them in a potential four-to-seven-game series,\" Irving said.\n\nYou just got to breathe through it. {"uri": "2024-06-378999270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "00:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T00:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T22:47:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://lastwordonsports.com/basketball/2024/06/04/lebron-james-gives-high-praise-to-former-teammate/", "title": "LeBron James Gives High Praise To Former Teammate", "body": "LeBron James was eliminated in the first round to the Denver Nuggets 4-1 this year and is getting ready to play for Team USA in this year's Olympics. Recently he had some interesting thoughts on one of his former teammates this week leading up to the NBA Finals. James on this week's \"Mind the Game\" podcast with J.J. Redick, had high praise for his former teammate Kyrie Irving.\n\n\"I have so many words to praise Kyrie that I ended up with absolutely none because he's the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen,\" James said. \"He has the best gifts I've ever seen of any NBA player.\"\n\nRedick even chimed in on Irving's game, calling it \"aesthetically pleasing and beautiful.\"\n\nLeBron James Gives High Praise To Former Teammate\n\nLeBron and Kyrie History\n\nJames and Irving played together for three years from 2014-2017 on the Cleveland Cavaliers, making it to three straight NBA Finals and winning just one in 2016. Both players benefited from each other and enjoyed playing with each other. However, Irving forced his way out and was traded to the Boston Celtics. Fast forward seven years and Irving is now on the Dallas Mavericks and helped lead them to the NBA Finals.\n\nWhen Irving left Cleveland there was some bad blood between him and James. Over time that bad blood went away and there were even talks this past offseason about him potentially playing with LeBron again in LA. Since LeBron is no longer teammates with Irving, he has to admire his talents from afar. One attribute in particular that LeBron is fond of is his ability to shoot with his weak hand. James said that if Irving is having an off night with his right hand he will just use his left for the rest of the game.\n\nWhat Makes Irving So Great\n\nA lot of people are probably wondering why Lebron said this about his former teammate. Besides the fact that he can shoot with his weak hand, he is also one of the best ball handlers in the NBA. Some of the moves he can pull off are just eye-dropping of how he can do them. He can shoot from all three levels, and he is also one of the best if not the best finishers ever in the NBA. Pretty much anything you can do offensively he is great at. Irving is also extremely clutch. Notably in Game 7 of the 2016 Finals, he hit one of the biggest shots in league history. There is a reason why LeBron said what he said about Irving and his admiration for his former teammate.\n\nThe Last Word\n\nIf it wasn't because of injuries and the Golden State Warriors creating the ultimate superteam by adding Kevin Durant. There is a real argument to be made that the Cavaliers could have won three straight NBA Finals. Irving may have never left and who knows how many rings they could have gotten together, that is how good this duo was. A timeline of his stint in Boston", "body": "Irving spent two years in Boston before signing with the Brooklyn Nets in 2019.\n\nKyrie Irving is back in the NBA Finals and the Boston Celtics are the only thing standing between him and his second championship.\n\nIrving has come a long way from his time in Boston. In Dallas, he paired with Luka Doncic to form one of the league's best backcourts and led the Mavericks to the Finals.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFive years after his ugly exit from Boston, Irving reflected on his time with the Celtics.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I know sometimes in sports, it's literally about the end goal and result and what you accomplish, and that's one thing,\" Irving said during the Mavericks' practice on Monday. \"But we're still human at the end of the day. I wasn't my best self during that time. When I look back on it, I just see it as a time where I learned how to let go of things and learned how to talk through my emotions.\n\nMavericks\n\nBe the smartest Mavericks fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\n\"It was just a chapter in my life that I got to enjoy for the most part. We had a great opportunity to do some special things, but it was cut short, just based off personal reasons on my end. One thing I look back on my time in Boston -- I've said this over the past few years, but somehow it gets tossed under the rug -- but the greatest thing I learned from Boston was just being able to manage not only my emotions or just what's going on on a day-to-day basis of being a leader of a team or being one of the leaders, and having young guys around you that have their own goals, but you have to learn how to put the big picture first.\"\n\nHere's a recap of Irving's history with the Celtics.\n\nAdvertisementAugust 2017: Traded to the Celtics\n\nIn August 2017, the Celtics acquired Irving in a trade with the Cleveland Cavaliers. The Celtics sent fan-favorite Isaiah Thomas, Jae Crowder, Ante Zizic and an unprotected first-round pick to Cleveland for Irving.\n\nAdvertisement2018: Misses first playoff run\n\nIrving made an immediate impact with the Celtics, averaging a team-high 24.4 points and 5.1 assists in his first season in Boston. However, a knee injury kept Irving out of the postseason.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWithout Irving, a rookie Jayson Tatum and second-year player Jaylen Brown led the Celtics to Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals, where they lost to LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers.\n\nOctober 2018: The promise\n\nIrving entered the 2018-19 season on an expiring contract. During a season-ticket holder event at TD Garden, Irving picked up a microphone and made a promise to Celtics fans.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"If you guys will have me back, I plan on re-signing here,\" Irving said to a cheering crowd.\n\nFebruary 2019: 'I don't owe anybody'\n\nBy February that same season, Irving had changed his tone.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIrving was asked if he still intended to re-sign with the Celtics in free agency.\n\n\"Ask me July 1,\" Irving said. \"At the end of the day, I'm going to do what's best for me and my career... I don't owe anybody.\"\n\nFebruary 2019: Meeting with Kevin Durant\n\nDuring NBA All-Star weekend later that February, a video leaked of Irving and then-Golden State Warriors star Kevin Durant meeting in the hallway.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDurant later admitted on his podcast that meeting was when he and Irving \"solidified that we were going somewhere.\"\n\nIrving was also asked about the exchange.\n\n\"What I do with my life is my business, so it's none of yours, it's none of anybody's. It's not anybody's business,\" Irving said. \"It's a video of me and one of my best friends talking. And then it turns out to be a dissection of a free-agency meeting? Do you get that? Like, do you get that? And then I'm asked questions about that? That's what disconnects me from all that.\"\n\nAdvertisementJuly 2019: Signs with Brooklyn\n\nIrving joined forces with Durant and signed a four-year, $142 million deal with the Brooklyn Nets in the offseason, ending his tenure with the Boston Celtics.\n\nDecember 2020: Burning sage\n\nIrving didn't make his return to Boston until the 2020-21 season after missing his first trip in 2019 due to an injury.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe December 2020 preseason game between the Nets and Celtics had no fans because of the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nBefore tipoff, Irving circled the court waving around a burning substance that appeared to be sage. Later, he said he did it to \"cleanse the energy\" in the arena.\n\nMay 2021: Booed in Boston\n\nIrving played his first game in front of the TD Garden crowd during the 2021 postseason.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPrior to Game 3 in Boston, Irving said he hoped fans would keep any jeers or insults strictly to basketball with \"no belligerence or any racism going on.\"\n\nFans booed Irving all game long any time he touched the ball. They cheered every time Irving missed a shot.\n\n\"It's basketball. I've been in a few environments in my life,\" Irving said after the game. \"As long as there's nothing extra, I'm cool with it.\"\n\nAdvertisementMay 2021: Stomping on Lucky\n\nThe intensity heightened the next game of the series.\n\nIrving rebounded well from a rough Game 3, scoring 39 points and 11 rebounds in the Nets' Game 4 win. However, things turned ugly afterward.\n\nAfter the final buzzer sounded, Irving high-fived his teammates and then stomped on the Celtics' logo at center court. Shortly after that as he was exiting the court, a water bottle was thrown in Irving's direction right before he exited the tunnel. A fan at TD Garden was arrested for allegedly throwing the drink at Irving.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"People just feel very entitled out here,\" Irving said after the game. \"They paid for the tickets. Great. I'm grateful they're coming in to watch a great performance. But we're not at the theatre. We're not throwing tomatoes and other random stuff at the people that are performing. It's too much. And it's a reflection on us as a whole\"\n\nApril 2022: Irving flips off Celtics fans\n\nIrving and the Nets met Boston again in the first round of the 2022 playoffs.\n\nIrving played well in Game 1, leading all scorers 39 points. However, he was clearly agitated with Celtics fans.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFans booed Irving all game and eventually, he was caught flipping the middle finger to fans several times.\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreWhat ex-NBA player says Mavs' Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving can expect from Celtics defenseNBA's best backcourt? {"uri": "8164567996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:28:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:28:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:27:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/nba/article-13498401/nba-finals-kyrie-irving-celtics-rivalry-racism.html", "title": "NBA Finals reignites Kyrie Irving's rivalry with the Celtics faithful", "body": "Since then, he's flipped off fans and accused the city of Boston of being 'racist'\n\nA once-promising union that has given way to five years of bitterness, Kyrie Irving's brief, rocky tenure with the Boston Celtics has dominated the spotlight heading into Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday night.\n\nThe Dallas Mavericks guard has done his best to downplay the friction, saying Wednesday that 'the fans are going to say what they're going to say, and I appreciate them.'\n\nBut Irving's benevolent turn might ring hollow to Celtics fans, who remain sour over his infamous 2019 defection to the Brooklyn Nets. Since then, he's likened the Boston faithful to a 'scorned girlfriend,' accused the fans of 'subtle racism,' burnt sage at the city's TD Garden to 'cleanse the energy' in the arena, stomped on the Celtics' mid-court logo, and famously flipped off the raucous crowd during last year's playoffs.\n\nNow in his first full season with the Mavs, Irving says he regrets the obscene hand gesture: 'When we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my s*** a little bit, that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level.'\n\nBut to Celtics fans, the moment was rewarding: The man who broke his promise to stay in Beantown in 2019 was clearly rattled, and by responding with an obscene hand gesture, he gave Bostonians ample motivation to continue the abuse throughout the upcoming Finals.\n\nKyrie Irving throws his arm around teammate Luka Doncic during Dallas' ongoing playoff run\n\nA Boston Celtics fan mocks Kyrie Irving with a t-shirt during a 2022 game at TD Garden\n\nOf course, things weren't always so rocky for Irving in the Massachusetts capital, where his father, Drederick, once played college ball for Rick Pitino at Boston University.\n\nIrving arrived in a 2017 trade with the Cleveland Cavaliers, and the initial returns were promising.\n\nDespite a season-ending injury to All-Star acquisition Gordon Hayward in the opener, the young Celtics overachieved in 2017-18 by finishing with the East's second-best record.\n\nThey would ultimately fall to LeBron James and the Cavaliers in the conference finals as Irving sat with knee problems, but Irving was nonetheless embraced in Boston. One fan had the All-Star's likeness shaved into the back of his head. Others pleaded for Irving's discarded wrist bands and sneakers after games, while a few had their clothing personally autographed by the former Duke star.\n\nAnd when Irving dismissed talk of his impending free agency at the onset of the 2018-19 season, instead predicting a long-term deal for himself in Boston, Celtics fans were positively overjoyed.\n\n'Obviously, a lot of great players have come before me, but to grow my name in Boston Celtics tradition and history is something I'm glad I can do, and I plan on,' Irving told reporters.\n\n'I do not want to uproot my family and just be dealing with anything new again,' he continued. 'No disrespect to other organizations, but here is perfect for me.'\n\nA Kyrie Irving fan shows off his favorite player's likeness on the back of his head in 2018\n\nKyrie Irving was happy to meet with fans and have his picture taken during his stint in Boston\n\nOne Kyrie Irving fan tried to goad the All-Star into signing an autograph for him in 2018\n\nUnfortunately, things began to unravel for Irving in 2018-19 as the Celtics fell to fourth in the East before losing to the Milwaukee Bucks in the second round of the playoffs.\n\nWorst of all, Irving was dismal in the fifth and final game, making just 6 of 21 field goals for 15 points, while finishing with a -25 plus-minus rating for the night.\n\nAs it turns out, Irving's tenure in Boston had been worsening for months.\n\nAlthough it wasn't known at the time, he'd been the subject of 2019 trade talks between the Celtics and rival New York Knicks, according to a recent report by Yahoo! Sports. The deal was never completed, but Irving was reportedly offered to New York in exchange for Kristaps Porzingis, the versatile 7-foot-3 center who was ultimately sent to Dallas and now starts for Boston.\n\nWhether Irving knew of the trade talks remains a mystery, but by the summer of 2019 he was reportedly looking to leave the Celtics in an effort to join friends Kevin Durant and DeAndre Jordan in Brooklyn. Soon thereafter, Irving confirmed his defection in early July by signing a four-year, $141million deal with the Nets.\n\nDejected Celtics fans responded by burning Irving jerseys on social media, but Boston's animosity towards the mercurial point guard didn't stop there. In the coming seasons with the Nets, Irving would be booed mercilessly by Celtics fans every time he touched the ball in Boston.\n\nThen, in June of 2021, a Celtics fan was arrested and ordered to stay away from the city's TD Garden after throwing a water bottle at Irving during a playoff game.\n\nThe hectic scene was eerily reminiscent of the 2002 Eastern Conference Finals, when Celtics focused their intense hatred New Jersey Nets All-Star Jason Kidd and his family.\n\n'You have to win with class and lose with class, and hopefully somebody will learn that,' Kidd, now the Mavericks head coach, said at the time. 'They have the right to cheer and boo. But there also is a fine line. You don't jeopardize anybody's family and friends in that sense of doing something ridiculous.'\n\nA man who was believed to throw a water bottle towards Irving is escorted out by security\n\nOf course, Kidd never accused Boston of 'subtle racism' as Irving has. Nor did he anger fans by stomping across the Celtics logo during the 2021 postseason.\n\nIrving, on the other hand, seemed to take pride in provoking the TD Garden crowd.\n\n'I know what to expect in here,' Irving said after a 2021 playoff game against Boston. 'And it's the same energy I'm giving back to them.'\n\nIrving and the Nets got the best of the Celtics in 2021, but it was Boston that swept Brooklyn in the first round of the 2022 postseason as Irving was reduced to flipping off the crowd at TD Garden.\n\nIn one instance, Irving celebrated a made 3-pointer by flipping off fans on his way down the court. Later, before an inbounds pass, Irving flashed both middle fingers to the crowd behind his head.\n\nAnd when one Celtics fan yelled 'Kyrie, you suck' as the Nets guard walked to the locker room, Irving snapped back, 'suck my d***, b****,' as seen on a viral TikTok video.\n\nHe later described the incidents as part of a tit-for-tat exchange with fans.\n\n'Look, where I'm from, I'm used to all these antics and people being close nearby,' the New Jersey native said after pouring in a team-high 39 points in the Game 1 loss. 'It's nothing new when I come into this building what it's going to be like -- but it's the same energy they have for me, I'm going to have the same energy for them.\n\n'And it's not every fan, I don't want to attack every fan, every Boston fan,' Irving continued. 'When people start yelling ''p****' or ''b****'' and ''f*** you'' and all this stuff, there's only but so much you take as a competitor. We're the ones expected to be docile and be humble, take a humble approach, f*** that, it's the playoffs. This is what it is.'\n\nIrving is still friendly with his ex-Celtics teammates, including Brown (right) and Tatum (left)\n\nInterestingly, Irving still has a good relationship with former Celtics teammates like Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, whom he described as 'very special people' during a friendly exchange with reporters this week.\n\nHe's also rejuvenated his career alongside Mavs star Luka Doncic, who has praised Irving as both a teammate and a leader.\n\nBut for all of the sudden positivity in Irving's life, he is just 1-10 against the Celtics since stomping on the team's logo in May of 2021.\n\nRead More Luka Doncic has his beer confiscated by Mavericks VP as he celebrated reaching the NBA Finals with his dad\n\nAny perceived frustration on Irving's part this series will only serve as encouragement for Celtics fans hoping for a record 18th NBA crown.\n\nAnd if Irving is going to have any chance at winning his second title, he's likely going to have to be the bigger person.\n\n'You just got to breathe through it,' Irving said earlier this week. 'To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions, what they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is. Don't overthink it.\n\n'Been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness,' he continued. 'It could all be turned into a strength. There's no fear out here, man.'\n\nAbove all, Irving believes it's he - and not the crowd - who will make the difference.\n\n'It's about the players at the end of the day.'", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378895424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "21:29:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T21:29:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T21:17:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/ranking-kyrie-irving-10-greatest-teammates", "title": "Ranking Kyrie Irving's 10 greatest teammates", "body": "Kyrie Irving is a star player that has made four trips to the NBA Finals. Let's look at Kyrie Irving's 10 greatest teammates.\n\nKyrie Irving is well-respected in the NBA, as he easily has the best handles in the league. Popularly known as Uncle Drew, Irving is an eight-time All-Star, three-time All-NBA Team selection, and an NBA champion.\n\nThese days, Irving is preparing for the NBA Finals with the Mavericks taking care of business in the playoffs. But while Irving has found success individually, he wouldn't have done it without some solid teammates. Let's rank Kyrie Irving's 10 greatest teammates.\n\n10. Ben Simmons\n\nBen Simmons' arrival in Brooklyn was supposed to be a fresh start for the three-time All-Star. Unfortunately, both Simmons and Irving never really played a lot of games together due to injuries. But when they did see action together, the duo showed some promise by posting an 18-12 record. However, Simmons is still one of the stars that was able to play alongside Irving.\n\n9. Gordon Hayward\n\nSpeaking of injuries, right from the get-go, Hayward's first game with Irving ended in catastrophe with the All-Star forward fracturing his ankle off an alley-oop play. Since then, Hayward was never the same. Although we saw flashes of what this duo could accomplish together, the Celtics could never make it to the Finals with Irving and Hayward.\n\n8. James Harden\n\nPrior to Ben Simmons joining the Nets, Brooklyn engaged in a blockbuster trade to first acquire former NBA MVP James Harden. With Harden's acquisition, the 10-time All-Star became Irving's third teammate who has previously won the MVP award.\n\nWhile Harden's acquisition was welcomed at first, the former MVP's struggles in the postseason wasn't helpful at all. Furthermore, their chemistry wasn't quite polished thanks to the lack of games played together with only 41.\n\n7. Al Horford\n\nWhile Irving was with the Celtics, a fellow veteran that helped him lead the team was All-Star big man Al Horford. Horford's skillset as a modern-day center ultimately elevated the Celtics into a formidable contender in the Eastern Conference. His ability to play inside and out made life a little easier for Irving during his stint in Boston.\n\n6. Jaylen Brown\n\nBack when Irving played for the Celtics, Jaylen Brown was still a rising star trying to find his footing in the NBA. Today, he's one of the Celtics' biggest stars.\n\nAlthough the Brown and Irving team-up wasn't as productive back in the day, Brown has improved by leaps and bounds today. A lot of that credit should also go to Irving for mentoring the promising Celtics core back in the day.\n\n5. Jayson Tatum\n\nAside from Jaylen Brown, the Celtics also invested in a young talented Jayson Tatum when they acquired Kyrie Irving from the Cavaliers. Like Brown, Tatum was still a young star back in the day.\n\nFast-forward to today, he has emerged as the Celtics' face of the franchise. While we never got to witness how a prime Tatum will work with Irving, it's safe to say that the Celtics are in good hands under Tatum's leadership.\n\n4. Kevin Love\n\nMany basketball fans will agree that the Cleveland Cavaliers wouldn't have won the NBA championship without their third star, Kevin Love. Like Horford was for the Celtics, Love had a polished inside and outside game that made life easier for Irving. Moreover, Love's respectable defense and elite rebounding was a huge lift for Irving's conquest of his first NBA title.\n\n3. Kevin Durant\n\nWhen Kevin Durant left the Warriors to team up with Irving in Brooklyn, the news immediately shocked the NBA world. The sky was the limit for the elite scoring duo.\n\nWhen healthy together, the duo would lead Brooklyn to 54 wins out of 88 games played together. However, off-court issues concerning Irving's vaccine stance, promotion of antisemitic content, and injuries never allowed this duo to showcase their full potential.\n\n2. Luka Doncic\n\nThere's no doubt that the Mavericks are in the NBA Finals thanks to the combustible duo of Irving and Luka Doncic. Although many critics have mentioned about the fit of Irving alongside Doncic, the duo has proved everyone wrong after their great playoff campaign thus far.\n\nThey eliminated the Los Angeles Clippers before taking care of business against the top-seeded Oklahoma City Thunder. They then earned a trip to the NBA Finals after a dominant series against the Timberwolves. Thanks to Doncic, a second NBA championship could be incoming for Irving.\n\n1. LeBron James\n\nThus far, there has been only one teammate quite like no other for Irving and that was LeBron James. Since James' return to Cleveland, Irving and The King formed an unstoppable duo as they led the Cavs to three-consecutive NBA Finals trips together while dominating the Eastern Conference.\n\nBut more importantly, it was this very duo that helped the Cavs win the franchise's first NBA championship at the expense of a 73-9 Warriors despite being down 3-1 in the 2016 NBA Finals.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "spencer_see@clutchpoints.com", "name": "Spencer See", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164900144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:54:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:54:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:50:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/kyrie-irving-hints-at-signing-long-term-extension-with-the-mavericks/article_df11d65e-c31d-5bb3-9ade-5952249a26f0.html", "title": "Kyrie Irving Hints At Signing Long-Term Extension With The Mavericks", "body": "Kyrie Irving remained coy when asked about his future in an ESPN interview with Mallika Andrews. While Irving stated that he keeps these things very fluid, he would not mind following in the footsteps of Nico Harrison, Jason Kidd, and potentially Luka Doncic this summer and signing a contract extension with the Mavericks.\n\n\"The future is still being written. But I can tell you that with all the extensions that are going around with J Kidd and Nico and potentially this summer with Luka, I think I don't mind being complimentary if we're going to continue to put this band together. We have some great pieces around us.\"\n\nIrving then spoke about the self-doubt he has faced on a regular basis during his NBA career, and how that affects his decisions. While Kyrie assesses things every season and focuses on basketball, he did state that he is very happy with his stint with the Mavericks.\n\n\"There's always those thoughts that will creep in - 'I'm just a what-if, what could happen?'. You never know, right? It's season to season. So, I just like to let it play out and stay in the present moment but I am enjoying my time here.\"\n\nIrving was traded to the Mavericks in 2023 after a tense situation with the Nets came to a head. While the Mavericks missed the playoffs that year, Irving seemingly bought into the vision of the franchise, re-signing with them for a two-year deal. This decision has paid dividends for both parties, as the Mavericks made the NBA Finals for the first time since 2011 with Kyrie on the team.\n\nAre Kyrie Irving And Luka Doncic The NBA's Next Dynastic Duo?\n\nDespite a shaky start playing together, Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving have gelled really well together, and have formed an incredibly dangerous back-court. Luka and Kyrie led the Mavericks during the playoffs and defeated some of the best teams in the NBA like the Clippers, the Thunder, and the Timberwolves to reach the NBA Finals.\n\nIrving has reminded many fans why he was considered one of the best players in the league with his performance this season. During the regular season, Irving averaged a strong 25.6 points, 5.2 assists, and 5.0 rebounds per game. And while his numbers dipped slightly in the playoffs, it was not a reflection of the quality of his play.\n\nDuring the playoffs, Irving has averaged 22.8 points, 5.2 assists, and 3.9 rebounds. His low scoring is mostly due to him not being the first option, and Luka Doncic having some very high-scoring games in the playoffs. Irving averaged 27.0 points, 4.6 assists, and 3.6 rebounds in the Western Conference Finals against the Timberwolves, taking his scoring up a level on the big stage.\n\nIrving will be playing against his former team, the Celtics in the 2024 NBA Finals. While the two sides had a bad falling out when Irving left the team in 2019, he still showed respect to the organization, claiming that he would not be where he is as a player today without his stint in Boston.\n\nIt will be a difficult series for Irving and the Mavericks, as the Celtics have long been considered the favorites to win the NBA championship. But the Mavericks have been defiant in the playoffs, and can never be counted out.\n\nRelated: Kyrie Irving Responds To LeBron James Reminiscing About Their Run Together: \"Appreciate How Much We've Been Able To Accomplish.\"\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8162361761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "07:10:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T07:10:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T07:09:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/jun/05/now-a-leader-for-dallas-irving-reflects-on-boston/", "title": "Now a leader for Dallas, Irving reflects on Boston", "body": "DALLAS -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago.\n\nIt was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavericks set to face the Boston Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday night.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player.\n\nThen came covid-19 and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavericks point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe former No. 1 overall pick out of Duke had never been anywhere near Texas in his career but was greeted by two familiar faces. Mavericks General Manager Nico Harrison used to work for Nike, and Coach Jason Kidd was the point guard of the then-New Jersey Nets when Irving was growing up in that area.\n\nIrving caught up with the team in Los Angeles after the trade, and the Mavericks won their first two games with him.\n\n\"You could see the smile,\" Kidd said. \"You could see the relief, or you could see that he was ready to have fun and play the game that he loves.\"\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. The first full season together was what the Mavericks expected when they pulled off Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\nA late-season surge lifted the Mavs to fifth in the West, although they've been the lower seed throughout these playoffs.\n\nDallas beat the Los Angeles Clippers in six games in the first round, ousting Tyronn Lue, Irving's coach from his championship season alongside LeBron James in Cleveland in 2016.\n\n\"He's very, very patient,\" Lue said after that series of the difference between the Irving he coached and today's version. \"You couldn't get this Kyrie when I had him. He wants to kill you every moment, every second. But now you can see, he's just letting the game come to him.\"\n\nThe Mavericks beat top-seeded Oklahoma City in six games before knocking out No. 3 Minnesota in five games in the Western Conference finals, the clincher giving Dallas a five-game road winning streak in the playoffs.\n\nIrving and Doncic have at least another season together. Irving has a player option for 2025-26, Doncic for the season after that.\n\nKidd believes a preseason trip to Madrid, where Doncic grew as a teenaged pro in the EuroLeague, helped the two superstars bond.\n\nNow, winning is cementing that bond, one of the most poignant moments for the pair coming in the final seconds of Game 3 against the Timberwolves, after the Mavericks knew they had clinched a 3-0 lead.\n\n\"When we were winning by nine on that last possession, I told (Irving), 'I'm tired,' and he told me, 'That's the way it's supposed to be,' \" Doncic said. \"He brought the calmness to the team and to me. He brought the maturity. I'm learning from him every day.\"\n\nThere might not have been many teammates lining up to say those things in Irving's first three stops, and the magnitude looms larger with the words coming from the face of the Dallas franchise.\n\nEven though his relationships with Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and some of his other former Boston teammates are fine, Irving believes he is a better teammate now than he was then.\n\n\"The greatest thing I learned from Boston was just being able to manage not only my emotions, but just what's going on on a day-to-day basis of being a leader of a team or being one of the leaders and having young guys around you that have their own goals,\" Irving said. \"You have to learn how to put the big picture first.\"\n\nA more introspective Irving is on the big stage again, and knows what's coming from the crowd in Boston.\n\nDallas Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving answers questions during a news conference after the Mavericks defeated the Minnesota Timberwolves in Game 5 of the NBA basketball Western Conference finals, Thursday, May 30, 2024, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Matt Krohn)\n\nDallas Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving gets off a shot against the Minnesota Timberwolves during the first half of Game 5 of the Western Conference finals in the NBA basketball playoffs, Thursday, May 30, 2024, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Matt Krohn)\n\nDallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (77) shakes hands with teammate Kyrie Irving (11) after their loss to the Minnesota Timberwolves in Game 4 of the NBA basketball Western Conference finals, Tuesday, May 28, 2024, in Dallas. {"uri": "8163842751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:28:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:28:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:27:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/nba/los-angeles-lakers/kyrie-irving-ribs-lebron-james-for-media-storm/", "title": "Lakers Star LeBron James Gets Shoutout From Kyrie Irving for 'Stirring up Media Storm'", "body": "Dallas Mavericks star Kyrie Irving was appreciative but also ribbed his former teammate, Los Angeles Lakers superstar LeBron James, for his viral compliment that kickstarted the conversation on the NBA Finals Media Day.\n\n\"Shout-out to LeBron for that. [He] Knows how to stir up a media storm, get everybody in here talking about us,\" Irving said on June 5 during the pre-NBA Finals presser.\n\nIrving was amused that the first question was neither about his current team nor his former team Boston Celtics, their opponents in the NBA Finals that begins on Thursday, June 6, in Boston.\n\n\"Is that the first question?\" Irving replied when Joe Vardon of The Athletic asked if he saw James' podcast comments complimenting him and missing playing with him. \"Oh, God, I love it! Got to love this, man!\"\n\nJames' comments, however, came within the NBA Finals preview in his \"Mind the Game\" podcast with ESPN analyst and Lakers' top coaching candidate JJ Redick.\n\n\"I will call Kyrie the wizard all the time,\" James said when Redick asked him about Irving. \"There was nothing on the basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do. I'm playing like so happy and so proud and to watch him and continue his growth and whatever the case and at the same time I'm so [expletive] mad at the same time that I am not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nJames and Irving wanted to team up anew at Los Angeles but it was nixed when the Brooklyn Nets rejected the Lakers' offer centered on Russell Westbrook and two future first-round picks in 2027 and 2029 last season, according to ESPN's Dave McMenamin. The Nets, instead, shipped Irving to Dallas for Spencer Dinwiddie, Dorian Finney-Smith, a 2029 first-round pick and second-round picks in 2027 and 2029.\n\nIrving pinned the blame on the aborted reunion on their respective team's decision-makers.\n\n\"Everything was considered,\" Irving told Mellisa Rohlin of Fox Sports on May 3. \"He's a great friend of mine, a great brother of mine. We obviously played together [in Cleveland]. Everybody knows our history. But there were so many different factors in between. When it comes to business decisions, you have to ask the GMs, the presidents why certain things didn't work out.\"\n\nJames was vocal that he missed Irving. The feeling is mutual.\n\n\"Definitely miss him,\" Irving said of the Lakers forward during the pre-NBA Finals presser on June 5. \"Playing out there, just making things easier, being able to run up and down the floor, just throw the ball to somebody like that, throw it in the air, as athletic as they come.\n\nYeah, just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table. His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I'm appreciative for the rest of my life.\"\n\nIrving appreciated James' compliment.\n\n\"I mean, I have a great reaction,\" Irving told reporters on June 5. \"It's appreciated. There's a lot of gratitude there, as well.\"\n\nThe Mavericks star also waxed nostalgic as he reminisced about his partnership with James in Cleveland that ended the city's NBA championship drought with the first 3-1 comeback in the NBA Finals history in 2016.\n\n\"Man, when he says comments like that, I think back to us having those moments where we're down in a series, up in a series, we're really demanding greatness from each other,\" Irving said. \"Off the court, our families meshing well.\n\nI definitely think about those times. Now we're here in the present where we're able to reflect but also now I'm at this stage, able to use some of the formulas that I was taught from him, some of the great teachers that have come before me. I feel like I've been built for this moment because I've gone through some of the things I've gone through in my past with some of the guys that have transcended the game.\"\n\nNow 32, Irving has a far different perspective than what he had when he demanded a trade out of Cleveland to step out of James' shadow.\n\n\"Obviously, I'm in a different age, a different place in my life,\" Irving said. \"So is he. I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\n\nI think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\"", {"uri": "8163468439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:21:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:21:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:20:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://celticswire.usatoday.com/lists/kyrie-irving-on-dealing-how-he-plans-to-handle-jeering-celtics-fans-in-nba-finals/", "title": "Kyrie Irving on dealing how he plans to handle jeering Celtics fans in NBA Finals", "body": "The Boston Celtics are back in the NBA Finals with a shot at winning an 18th title and raising a championship banner for the first time since 2008. Winning it all means squaring off with a familiar foe.\n\nKyrie Irving is in his second season with the Dallas Mavericks, and one of the club's top offensive weapon. He will be critical to Dallas' scoring attack, but much of the commentary leading up to the series has been how Irving will contend not with Boston's defenders but with the fans in the rafters. Irving spent two seasons with the Celtics before joining the Brooklyn Nets in free agency, and his relationship with Boston has been tumultuous ever since. With the series set to tip Thursday at TD Garden, Irving was asked about how he feels about the city and his old teammates.\n\nIrving acknowledged how much history he has with the city of Boston, but that he is ready to focus on basketball.\n\n\"I've experienced Boston twofold,\" Irving explained. \"My first few years being in the NBA playing for the Cavs, then coming here to Boston, then being right down the street in Brooklyn, now being here in the Finals playing against them in a potential four-to-seven-game series. You just got to breathe through it.\"\n\nIrving made it clear that previous exchanges with Celtics fans were indeed emotional in both directions. The 32-year-old outlined how it is best to channel those feelings into something more constructive.\n\n\"To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions,\" Irving said. \"What they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is. Don't overthink it.\n\n\"I've been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety,\" Irving said. \"Some of that is nervousness. It could all be turned into a strength. There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball. The fans are going to say what they're going to say. I appreciate them and their relationship they have to the game. But it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nPlaying in Boston isn't just about reuniting with fans in the stand for Irving. He was asked about squaring off with his former teammates Jaylen Brown, Jayson Tatum, and Al Horford.\n\n\"I'm excited,\" Irving said. \"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them. I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level, playing against the best of the best.\n\nIrving continued sharing his excitement about the upcoming series and the respect he has for his opponent.\n\n\"They have a great team over there led by a great coach,\" Irving said. \"So we're going to be in for a great series, hard, tough series. They're going to give us their best. I know they're not going to slow down when they see me. They're going to come at me even more.\"\n\n\"This is what I've been preparing for since last summer, or when our season ended last year,\" Irving continued. \"Putting in the time to prepare for moments like this.\"\n\nGame 1 of the NBA Finals is in Boston, and at the time of this writing, the Celtics are favored to win the series. {"uri": "8164011824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:20:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://essexnewsdaily.com/sports/sports-westorange/west-oranges-kyrie-irving-leads-dallas-mavericks-to-nba-finals", "title": "West Orange's Kyrie Irving leads Dallas Mavericks to NBA Finals", "body": "WEST ORANGE, NJ -- Kyrie Irving is headed back to the NBA Finals.\n\nThe West Orange native, one of the best players in the league, will lead the Dallas Mavericks in the NBA Finals against the Boston Celtics. Game 1 is Thursday, June 6, and Game 2 is Sunday, June 9, in Boston. Irving previously played for the Celtics for two seasons (2017-18 and 2018-19).\n\nThe 32-year-old dynamic point guard helped the Mavericks to a 4-1 series win over the Minnesota Timberwolves in the Western Conference Finals. He and fellow superstar Luca Doncic each scored 36 points in the clinching 124-103 win on Thursday, May 30. Irving had 30 points in the 108-105 win in Game 1, and 33 points in the 116-107 win in Game 3.\n\nIn 17 games this postseason, Irving has averaged 22.8 points and 5.2 assists per game.\n\nIrving is in the NBA Finals for the fourth time in his illustrious 13-year career. He led the Cleveland Cavaliers to the NBA title with megastar LeBron James in 2016, when the team defeated the Golden State Warriors. The Cavs and Warriors met in the NBA Finals in four straight years, with the Warriors winning in 2015, 2017 and 2018.\n\nIrving joined the Mavericks after being traded from the Brooklyn Nets in February 2023. He played three-plus seasons in Brooklyn (2019-20 to 2022-23). After spending more than a year in Minnesota, Irving regards his tenure with the Mavericks as the most rewarding phase of his career.\n\nIn a candid interview with Vincent Goodwill from Yahoo, Irving shared his reflections on his time with the Mavericks.\n\n\"This has been the greatest portion of my career. To be able to now give wisdom and also speak from a place of experience. When you're a young person, again, you're trying to speed through life, you're trying to get through everything,\" Irving said.\n\nSince joining the Mavericks, Irving seems to have found a renewed passion for basketball. This season, he has averaged an impressive 25.6 points, 5.0 rebounds, and 5.2 assists per game in the regular season.\n\nIrving's leadership and on-court performance have been pivotal for the Mavericks, especially in the postseason. One of his standout performances came in Game 5 of the Western Conference Finals, where the follower of Kobe Bryant scored 36 points. This crucial game helped propel the Mavericks to the NBA Finals after 13 years.\n\nKyrie Irving is set to enter his fourth NBA final. After reaching his first NBA final with the Mavericks, Irving took a moment to praise the team's head coach, Jason Kidd.\n\nThe 2011 No. 1 overall pick recently expressed his gratitude to Kidd for stretching his helping shoulder for Irving.\n\n\"Coming to Dallas, just being around J Kidd, somebody who also can relate to me about being imperfect and, and having mistakes in their life and being able to redeem themselves and persevere. Still answer to the naysayers,\" Irving said.\n\nThe Mavericks' fans and the entire organization are now eagerly watching Irving, hoping he can replicate his remarkable performance from the 2016 NBA Finals. While the Celtics are strong favorites, Dallas does seem to have a real shot at winning it all.\n\nOn the \"Mind the Game\" podcast, James said that he's \"mad\" he isn't teammates with Irving.\n\nVia ESPN:\n\n\"I'm so [expletive] happy and so proud to watch him continue his growth,\" James told his co-host, JJ Redick. \"I'm so [expletive] mad at the same time that I'm not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nJames' Los Angeles Lakers made a couple of attempts to trade for Irving not too long ago and reunite Irving with the four-time MVP. {"uri": "2024-06-380674588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:00:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:00:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.espn.com.sg/nba/story/_/id/40286946/mavs-kyrie-irving-appreciative-lebron-james-compliments", "title": "Kyrie: Kind words from LeBron 'appreciated'", "body": "Covered the Lakers and NBA for ESPNLosAngeles.com from 2009-14, the Cavaliers from 2014-18 for ESPN.com and the NBA for NBA.com from 2005-09.\n\nBOSTON -- Dallas Mavericks star Kyrie Irving couldn't help but flash an incredulous smile when, on the eve of Game 1 of the NBA Finals, the first question that came his way Wednesday was about a former teammate rather than his current Finals foe.\n\nThen again, LeBron James isn't just any teammate.\n\n\"Is that the first question?\" Irving said when asked about James' recent podcast comments stating he is \"f---ing mad\" to not be teaming up with the eight-time All-Star any longer. \"Oh, God, I love it. Got to love this, man.\"\n\nMore questions about other former teammates of Irving's on the Boston Celtics followed, of course. Boston was the point guard's landing spot after he was traded away from James and the Cleveland Cavaliers in summer 2017.\n\nBut the first order of business was James, whom he teamed up with for three seasons from 2014 to 2017 and made three straight trips to the Finals, winning it all together in 2016 in a memorable seven-game series against a record-setting Golden State Warriors team that went 73-9 in the regular season.\n\nIrving said he \"appreciated\" James' sentiments on his \"Mind the Game\" podcast with JJ Redick, when James lauded the former No. 1 pick as \"the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nAnd seven years after playing together, Irving, 32, said his relationship with the 39-year-old James has only flourished.\n\n\"Obviously, I'm in a different age, different place in my life. So is he. I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish,\" Irving said. \"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\"\n\nIrving, who was traded to Dallas from the Brooklyn Nets last season after James' Los Angeles Lakers made a run at acquiring him, reciprocated the wistfulness.\n\n\"Definitely miss him,\" Irving said. \"Man, when he says comments like that, I think back to us having those moments where we're down in a series, up in a series, we're really demanding greatness from each other. Off the court, our families meshing well. ... I definitely think about those times.\"\n\nJames and Irving's Cavs became the first team in to come back from a 3-1 deficit to win the Finals in 2016. Game 5 of that series, the first of their three straight wins to close it out, was also historic as James and Irving became the first teammates ever to both score 40-plus points in the same Finals game.\n\nAll of the success they shared, however, left the then-25-year-old Irving feeling incomplete. Sources told ESPN that during Irving's last postseason run with the Cavs in 2017, he went consecutive days in between playoff series reporting to the team's practice facility without speaking to any teammates.\n\nIt was something Irving indirectly acknowledged when asked about the ups and downs he has experienced since requesting a trade out of Cleveland to finally finding a comfort zone all these years later with the Mavs.\n\n\"Basketball has been a great teacher for me, but life has been an even better one,\" Irving said. \"Using those same principles I've learned in life apply to basketball has allowed me to connect to my teammates better. There's no silent treatment that's coming randomly throughout the year because I don't know how to emotionalize or vocalize how I'm feeling. Some of the things I struggled with as a young player, I've now been able to accept this is what comes with being in this position. Taking on the pressure. Then also teaching my teammates how to get through it.\"\n\nIt's the same role that James took on with him.\n\n\"Now we're here in the present where we're able to reflect, but also now I'm at this stage, able to use some of the formulas that I was taught from [James], some of the great teachers that have come before me,\" Irving said. \"I feel like I've been built for this moment because I've gone through some of the things I've gone through in my past with some of the guys that have transcended the game.\"\n\nAnd Irving had one more compliment for the league's all-time leading scorer.\n\n\"Shoutout to LeBron for that,\" Irving said. \"Knows how to stir up a media storm, get everybody in here talking about us.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com.sg", "dataType": "news", "title": They've been championship teammates, there's been reported rifts, and now, there's nothing but love, as James and JJ Redick gushed about Irving on the latest Mind the Game Pod.\n\nLeBron lamented about having to watch Irving from the sidelines instead of being on the court with him, and as reported by Ramona Shelburne of ESPN, they were almost teammates again on the Los Angeles Lakers.\n\nWhen asked about Irving, LeBron couldn't stop complimenting Irving. \"I will call Kyrie the wizard all the time. There was nothing on the basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do. I'm playing like so happy and so proud and to watch him and continue his growth and whatever the case and at the same time I'm so fucking mad at the same time that I am not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nWhile reminiscing about the absurd ability of Irving, LeBron almost couldn't find the words to describe it, saying, \"I just remember those times. The most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nA former NBA Rookie of the Year, Irving's career averages of 23.6 points, 5.7 assists and 1.3 steals are quite impressive. The 50/40/90 club is meant to separate the best shooters in the league and historically, it's held a lot of weight. After putting together a shooting line of .497/.411/.905 in 2023-24, Irving's career averages rose to .474/.393/.886.\n\nIrving doesn't always get the praise he deserves, as shockingly his trophy case is awfully barren. His allure and his highlight package stand up against anyone who has ever played, yet Irving has never received any MVP consideration and has made just three All-NBA teams. What other players say about Irving, however, speaks volumes.\n\nJJ Redick chimed in with, \"I'm not sure there's ever been a player that's more aesthetically pleasing.\"\n\nFair or not, Irving became a source of contention amongst basketball fans during the COVID-19 pandemic. His unwillingness to get vaccinated was a big story, reportedly costing him the ability to sign a 4-year, $100 million extension with the Brooklyn Nets.\n\nA frustrated Irving said, \"I didn't appreciate how me being vaccinated, all of a sudden, came to be a stigma within my career that I don't want to play, or I'm willing to give up everything to be a voice for the voiceless.\"\n\nThe 2024 NBA Finals and essentially this entire run have proven to be a valuable opportunity to turn the focus back to Irving's basketball ability and away from his polarizing statements on things like the shape of the Earth.\n\nHaving already won an NBA Championship alongside LeBron for the Cleveland Cavaliers, Irving can join an elite list of players to win championships for multiple franchises. The Dallas Mavericks are underdogs to the Boston Celtics, but the AP is reporting that the public is pushing the line the other way at BetMGM Sportsbook, with 80% of the bets coming in being put on the Mavericks to win the title.\n\nUnfortunately, LeBron will have to continue to watch from the outside, wondering what could have been.", "source": {"uri": "heavy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8162173185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "04:39:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T04:39:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T04:39:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/nba/im-so-fcking-mad-lebron-james-regrets-for-not-being-running-mate-with-most-gifted-nba-playe/", "title": "\"I'm So F*cking Mad\"- LeBron James Regrets For Not Being Running Mate With 'Most Gifted NBA Playe", "body": "The Los Angeles Lakers have struggled to maintain their momentum this season, while the Dallas Mavericks, led by Kyrie Irving, have secured a spot in the NBA Finals. As Irving prepares for his first NBA Finals appearance since 2017, his former teammate LeBron James has openly expressed how much he misses playing alongside him.\n\nIn this week's episode of the \"Mind the Game\" podcast, LeBron shared his admiration and regret, calling Irving the \"most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\n\"[I'm] so f*cking happy to watch him continue his growth, and at the same time, I'm so f*cking mad that I am not his running mate anymore. He's the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen,\" James said.\n\nIrving's journey with the Mavericks has been remarkable, and his growth this season has silenced his critics, including long-time critic Stephen A. Smith.\n\nIrving's athleticism was particularly evident in the Western Conference Finals against the Minnesota Timberwolves. Throughout the series, he accumulated an impressive 135 points, 18 rebounds, and 23 assists. His stellar performance was crucial in propelling the Mavericks into the NBA Finals after 13 years.\n\nLeBron James and Kyrie Irving played three seasons with the Cleveland Cavaliers from 2014 to 2017, creating a dynamic partnership that captivated fans. Their on-court chemistry led the Cavaliers to three consecutive NBA Finals appearances, culminating in a historic championship win in 2016.\n\nNevertheless, the duo's time together ended when Irving requested a trade out of Cleveland in the summer of 2017. He eventually joined the Boston Celtics, and the two have not played together since then.\n\nApart from teammates, they have faced each other 16 times as opponents in NBA games. The star point guard spent two seasons with the Celtics from 2017 to 2019, and things did not go well. Irving openly said he planned to re-sign with Boston before leaving to join Kevin Durant on the Brooklyn Nets. The relationship between Irving and Celtics fans has since been tenuous, to say the least.\n\nMany have wondered how or if Irving will be impacted by the hostile environment, but he said he already has a plan in place to deal with it.\n\n\"You just gotta breathe through it,\" Irving said. \"To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions and what they're saying to you, you have to breathe and realize that this is not as hostile as you think it is. I've been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety and some of that is nervousness, and it can all be turned into a strength.\"\n\nIrving said earlier this week that he regrets his past interactions with Celtics fans, which have included him making multiple obscene gestures toward the TD Garden crowd. {"uri": "8161782365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "20:57:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T20:57:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T20:55:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/mavericks/2024/06/04/lebron-james-praises-mavericks-guard-kyrie-irving-he-has-the-best-gifts-ive-ever-seen/", "title": "LeBron James praises Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving: 'He has the best gifts I've ever seen'", "body": "While watching Dallas in the playoffs, James admits to being \"mad\" about no longer being teammates with Irving due to his current level of play.\n\nLeBron James and Kyrie Irving have a history.\n\nWhen James took his talents from South Beach back to Cleveland, the pair of former No. 1 overall picks led the Cavaliers to an NBA title in 2016, overcoming a 3-1 series deficit against the Golden State Warriors.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Cavaliers would represent the Easter Conference in the NBA finals again the next season -- this time falling to Golden State -- before Irving requested a trade in the 2017 offseason, wanting to be the primary option on his own team.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDespite the forced separation, James still holds great admiration for Irving's skills on the court. Rumors even swirled last offseason that Irving, a free agent at the time, could rejoin James with the Los Angeles Lakers before he eventually re-upped his deal with the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nMavericks\n\nBe the smartest Mavericks fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nAs the Mavericks prepare to face the Boston Celtics -- another former Irving stomping ground -- in the NBA Finals, James poured out multiple compliments (some NSFW) about his former teammate on his \"Mind the Game\" podcast with former Mavericks guard J.J. Reddick ahead of Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I would call Kyrie the wizard all the time, like, all the time. There was nothing on a basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do. ... [I'm] so proud to watch him continue his growth and whatever the case may be, and ... mad at the same time that I am not his running mate anymore,\" James said.\n\nThe four-time league MVP also called Irving the \"ultimate wildcard\" as he described his own realization during the Western Conference finals that the pairing of Irving alongside Luka Doncic would be capable of claiming its own NBA championship trophy.\n\n\"I have so many words to praise Kyrie that I end up with absolutely none. Because it's just, he's the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen. He has the best gifts I've ever seen of any NBA player,\" James said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I've never seen a guy in my NBA life that feels better at times shooting with his off hand than he does with his with his primary. If Kyrie is off in a game with his right hand, he will literally go exclusively to his left hand. I've never seen nothing like that. The shot, one thing I'm thinking, the shot that he made versus Denver, towards the end of the regular season on Joker [Nikola Joki\u0107] is one of the most ridiculous shots I've ever seen in my life. He's just that special.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn 17 games this postseason, Irving is averaging 22.8 points, 5.2 assists and and 3.9 rebounds a game. He is shooting 48.5% from the floor (42.1% from three-point range) while playing 40.2 minutes a night.\n\n\"I'm not sure there's ever been a player that's more aesthetically pleasing when he has it going,\" said Reddick. \"His game is beautiful, you know what I'm saying? He always talks about how basketball players are artists. He's an artist on the court. And I got to be honest, like, it's not invalid. Sometimes like, yeah, this guy's an artist. You called him a wizard, I'll call him an artist.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJames: \"We're both saying the exact same thing. I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was younger.\"\n\nKyrie and LeBron in Cleveland fell apart\n\nIrving was supposed to be the Cleveland Cavaliers' next franchise player when they picked him first overall in the 2011 NBA Draft. Still, after winning their first ring together, they fell apart, with Irving wanting a bigger role.\n\nKyrie left for Boston and then Brooklyn but did not find success there. He was traded to the Mavs last season and has since found a home there. Irving believes the events that led him to Dallas have prepared him for the 2024 NBA Finals.\n\n\"I feel like I've been built for this moment because I've gone through some of the things I've gone through in my past with some of the guys that have transcended the game,\" Irving added. \"Shout-out to LeBron for that. Ultimately, this will be a series with several narratives. One narrative involves Irving attempting to win his second Larry O'Brien Championship Trophy. First, he started hot, with 31 points in Game 1 of the Western Conference Quarterfinals. Irving also exploded for 40 points in Game 4 of that same series. Next, he helped the Mavs close out the Clippers in Game 6 with 30 points.\n\nThe series against the Oklahoma City Thunder did not go as smoothly. Yet, he did enough to help power the Mavericks to the Western Conference Finals for a showdown with the Minnesota Timberwolves. That is where Irving turned it up a notch. Amazingly, he really came alive at times during the Conference Finals and made some great things happen.\n\nIrving started the series hot with 30 points in Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals. Later, he had 33 points in Game 3 to help put the Wolves on the edge of elimination. After he struggled in Game 4, he knew he had to step it up even more. Irving tacked on 36 points in Game 5 to help seal Minnesota's fate and give the Mavericks their ticket to their first NBA Finals appearance since they won their championship in 2011.\n\nIrving averaged 26.5 points per game against the Clippers in the first round. Then, he averaged only 15.6 points per game against the Thunder. But he bounced back properly against the Wolves, averaging 27 points per game.\n\nIrving has shown that he is capable of completely taking over a game. Amazingly, the Mavs are 5-1 in the postseason when he scores at least 40 points. The Mavericks are also 3-1 when he scores under 20 points. Overall, this is a very successful team. But they are almost guaranteed to win when he scores 30 points.\n\nThe Celtics likely will have several choices on who guards Irving. Significantly, Jrue Holiday, Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, and Derrick White can all take turns guarding him. Irving will do everything in his power to help the Mavs and score as many points as possible to get his team the victory.\n\nIrving will hit the over because he has demonstrated an ability to show up in high-pressure situations. Then, he will maneuver his way past this difficult Boston defense.\n\nWhy Kyrie Irving Will Hit the Under\n\nBut this defense is challenging to overcome. Substantially, they can shut down a big-time player. When they played the Cavaliers, they allowed Donovan Mitchell to thrive. But the Celtics shut everyone else down. Consider the fact that Luka Doncic may go off. Yet, Boston might focus more on shutting Irving down if they believe he is the bigger threat.\n\nIrving had some bad games during the playoffs.
