{"uri": "8163555868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:44:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:44:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:43:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://blackamericaweb.com/2024/06/05/nba-finals-kyrie-irving-faces-celtics-3-years-after-calling-out-bostons-anti-black-racism/", "title": "NBA Finals: Kyrie Irving Faces Celtics 3 Years After Calling Out Bosto", "body": "Black America Web Featured Video CLOSE\n\nSource: David Berding / Getty\n\nKyrie Irving is no stranger to controversy and isn't one to hold his tongue when it comes to issues he believes in. When Irving played in Boston and Brooklyn, he had some heavy criticisms from Celtics fans.\n\nThree years later, he's returning to Boston as a member of the Dallas Mavericks to face his former team in the NBA Finals and the fans he once called out for their \"subtle racism\" towards him and his teammates.\n\nIrving spent two years playing for the Boston Celtics before leaving to join Kevin Durant and the Brooklyn Nets in 2019.\n\nThe next year, Irving and the Nets met the Celtics in the NBA Playoffs where they took a convincing 2-0 lead in the seven-game series. Before the series headed to Boston, Irving expressed to the media that he hoped his return to Boston wasn't tainted by fans being racist.\n\n\"Hopefully we can just keep it strictly basketball,\" Irving said during the post-game press conference. \"There's no belligerence or racism going on, subtle racism, and people yelling [expletive] from the crowd. Even if it is, it's part of the nature of the game and we're just going to focus on what we can control.\"\n\nKyrie added about his claims of racism in Boston: \"I'm not the only one who could attest to this . . . but it's just, it is what it is. The whole world knows it.\"\n\nDuring the next two games in Boston, Kyrie had multiple interactions with angry Celtics fans, including a fan being arrested for throwing a water bottle at him after Brooklyn's Game 4 win.\n\nBut it didn't stop there.\n\nIn 2022, Irving was fined $50,000 for flashing his middle finger at Boston fans during the Nets' Game 1 playoff loss in 2022, according to ESPN.\n\nNow, Irving, who seems to be happy and thriving in his new environment said he had regrets about past interactions with Boston fans and is in a better place emotionally.\n\n\"I think I'm better at consolidating kind of the emotions now or being aware of what it's going to be like,\" Irving told ESPN after the Mavericks' Monday practice. \"We call it animosity, we call it hate, we call it, 'It's going to be hell in Boston.' I mean, there are real, live circumstances going on in the world that are bigger than the basketball, kind of the competitive side of things and answering those questions.\"\n\nHe continued, \"But I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my s -- a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level. It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nIrving also acknowledged his growth as a human since his short tenure in Boston and says he looks forward to the challenge.\n\n\"I'm built for these moments, to be able to handle circumstances like that, and I've been able to grow since then. So of course it's going to be a hectic environment, but I'm looking forward to it and I see it as a healthy relationship that I have with the fans. I almost think about 'Gladiator,' just winning the crowd over. It is good to hear the TD Garden silent when you're playing well. {"uri": "2024-06-380841126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:18:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:18:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:25:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/sports/basketball/nba-finals-how-kyrie-irving-became-the-most-hated-man-in-boston-celtics", "title": "NBA Finals: How Kyrie Irving became the most hated man in Boston Celtics?", "body": "The moment is here, the stage is set as Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks are going to lock horns in the 2024 NBA Finals.\n\nThe finals are touted to be one of the most anticipated and exciting matchup since the Steph Curry led Golden State Warriors and the LeBron James led Cleveland Cavaliers finals era. There is definitely a lot of focus on young superstars in Jayson Tatum and Luka Doncic facing off against one another to bring their respective franchises the Championship Glory.\n\nHowever, one of the biggest talking points is Kyrie Irving returning to face his former team and a city in which there is a lot of bad blood and he is one of the most hated players Ahead of a matchup for generations, let's look at the bad bloos between Kyrie Irving and Boston Celtics.\n\nAlso Read | Luka Doncic Injury Update: Is Mavs star fit to play in NBA Finals Game 1\n\nWhy Kyrie Irving is hated by Boston Celtics?\n\nKyrie Irving was acquired by Boston Celtics on his existing deal with the Cleveland Cavaliers and he arrived at the Garden to be their next generational superstar and the face of the Celtics to take them to the promised land.\n\nHowever, his two years with Boston were filled with injuries and frustrations as it never really clicked. Kyrie Irving's was set to be a Free Agent in Free Agency 2019 and he promised the TD Garden faithful that he plans on resigning in free agency.\n\nBut that promise was broken when Kyrie Irving stunned everyone and signed with the Brooklyn Nets after a tumultuous season with the Celtics. There was no turning back for the Celtics fans as Kyrie Irving became the public enemy number 1 in Boston.\n\nThings escalated when Kyrie Irving returned to face the Boston Celtics with Brooklyn Nets at TD Garden and burned a sage saying he wanted to 'cleanse the energy'. While burning sage is a tradition in indegineous culture, the Celtics fans didn't take too kindly with the action.\n\nTo make it even worse, Kyrie Irving also stomped on the Boston Celtics logo and during a playoffs game when Boston Celtics started the Kyrie Suck chants, 'Hela' flipped off the fans at TD Arena.\n\nAlso Read | Boston Celtics Injury Report: Huge Kristaps Porzingis BOOST ahead of NBA Finals Game 1 vs Mavericks\n\nA New Chapter with the Mavericks awaits\n\nAfter a tumultuous stint at Brooklyn Nets as well, Kyrie moved to Dallas Mavericks and seemed to have found peace with the franchise and has emerged as one of the leaders in the team.\n\nKyrie Irving with Luka Doncic of Dallas Mavericks, Image/AP\n\nAhead of the game Kyrie admitted that he regrets flipping off the Boston faithful, \"Last time in Boston, everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my s--- a little bit. That wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level\".\n\nWhile Kyrie is cautious it is going to be a hostile environment for him Boston, he is looking forward to the Irving was dealt to Boston and a couple of seasons later, the two stars developed a deeper appreciation for each other when Irving reconnected with James for guidance on how to lead the young Celtics the way the four-time MVP had led the Cavs.\n\nLast season, the Los Angeles Lakers were one of several teams to aggressively pursue Irving leading up to the trade deadline before the Brooklyn Nets ultimately sent him to Dallas in a package that included Spencer Dinwiddie, Dorian Finney-Smith, an unprotected first-round pick in 2029 and two second-round picks. The Lakers' offer centered on Russell Westbrook and two future first-round picks in 2027 and 2029, sources told ESPN.\n\nJames, who openly lobbied for L.A. to acquire Irving, lamented the point guard landing with the Mavs at the time.\n\n\"I can't sit here and say I'm not disappointed on not being able to land such a talent, but [also] someone that I had great chemistry with, and know I got great chemistry with on the floor, that can help you win championships, in my mind, in my eyes,\" James told ESPN's Michael Wilbon last February.\n\nWhile the Celtics are the favorites in the Finals (-225, according to ESPN BET), James said that Irving's presence makes the Mavericks more than just an underdog. {"uri": "8161538533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:20:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:20:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:19:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/lebron-james-is-so-f-mad-kyrie-irving-isnt-on-his-team-anymore-calls-him-most-gifted-player-ever/", "title": "LeBron James is 'so f****** mad' Kyrie Irving isn't on his team anymore, calls him 'most gifted player' ever - CBSSports.com", "body": "USATSI\n\nLeBron James played with Kyrie Irving on the Cleveland Cavaliers from 2014 through 2017. In their three seasons as teammates, Cleveland reached the NBA Finals three times. The pair won the 2016 championship together, and were it not for Irving's injury in 2015 and a once-in-a-lifetime cap spike allowing Kevin Durant to join the Golden State Warriors in time for the 2017 series, they easily could have won three consecutive titles together. While both have enjoyed individual success since separating, neither has won nearly as consistently without the other.\n\nJames has, on a number of occasions, come close to reuniting with Irving. The Los Angeles Lakers have pursued him several times. Last summer, Irving reportedly wanted James to join him with the Dallas Mavericks. Those deals never materialized, and now Irving is set to play in the NBA Finals as a member of the Mavericks. James is enjoying watching his former teammate flourish, but at the same time, he won't deny how much he misses playing with his former protege.\n\n\"There was nothing on the basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do,\" James explained on his Mind the Game podcast with JJ Redick. \"And sitting here watching it, I'm like, I'm playing like, so f******* happy and so proud to watch him continue his growth and whatever the case may be, and at the same time, I am so f******* mad at the same time that I am not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nJames said he was \"disappointed\" when the Lakers failed to land Irving at the 2023 deadline, and it's not hard to see why. The Lakers have spent virtually the entire James era looking for a long-term point guard to do for James what Irving once did. They've failed on smaller additions like Dennis Schroder and D'Angelo Russell. They've failed with bigger ones like Russell Westbrook. No guard aside from Dwyane Wade has ever paired more perfectly with James. Irving eased the scoring burden on his former running mate, and James ensured that he wouldn't have to focus as much on the playmaking that has never come quite as easily to him. That's one of the few things that doesn't come naturally to Irving because, according to James, his former point guard is \"the most gifted player\" in NBA history.\n\n\"I have so many words to praise Kyrie that I end up with absolutely none, because it's just, it's so, he's the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen,\" James said. \"He has the best gifts I've ever seen of any NBA player. I've never seen a guy in my NBA life that feels better at times shooting with his off-hand than he does with his primary hand. If Kyrie's off in a game with his right hand, he will literally go exclusively to his left hand. I've never seen nothing like that.\"\n\nThat is high praise coming from anyone, but especially James, who himself is routinely considered the most physically gifted player in NBA history. Those two notions can coexist. James has physical tools no NBA player has ever had, but Irving has a combination of skills and moves on the ball that have never been matched. Together, the two formed one of the most potent offensive duos the league will ever see. It only lasted three years, but if James had his way, it would have lasted a whole lot longer.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164026253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:34:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:34:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:32:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/kyrie-irving-leave-celtics-promise-nets/85f6bc4afeac27caa1012f4d", "title": "Why did Kyrie Irving leave the Celtics? Revisiting guard's promise to Boston, decision to sign with Nets", "body": "It will only take one possession with the ball in Kyrie Irving's hands during the 2024 NBA Finals to realize Celtics fans still aren't over the All-Star guard's exit from Boston.\n\nAlthough it may feel like a decade ago, we're only five seasons removed from Irving's two-year stint with the Celtics.\n\nThe star guard was acquired by Boston in a 2017 blockbuster trade that sent former All-NBA guard Isaiah Thomas to the Cavaliers. Irving was supposed to be the superstar to take the Celtics' young core over the top in pursuit of a championship, but the team never reached the potential that it had on paper.\n\nAfter two seasons of injuries and on- and off-court issues, Irving elected to leave Boston in free agency despite making promises that he'd stay. Here's what led to the falling out of his time with the Celtics.\n\nMORE: Jayson Tatum gets candid about Irving's disappointing Celtics run\n\nInjuries plagued the Celtics during Irving's first season in Boston. All-Star forward Gordon Hayward went down with a season-ending leg injury in the first game, then Irving underwent season-ending knee surgery just over a week before the playoffs started.\n\nThe Celtics still reached Game 7 of the 2018 Eastern Conference Finals without their two All-Stars, as rookie Jayson Tatum and second-year Jaylen Brown began to emerge into the players they would become today. That left confusion in the locker room as the team suddenly had too many mouths to feed from a scoring standpoint.\n\nIrving entered a contract year in 2018-19 and decided not to sign an extension before the start of the season. Despite that decision, he pledged his loyalty to Boston during a preseason fan event that led Celtics faithful to believe he'd re-sign at the end of the year.\n\n\"If you guys will have me back, I plan on re-signing here,\" Irving told the TD Garden crowd.\n\nHe doubled down in an interview with the media the following day, saying he wanted his number retired in Boston.\n\n\"I have every intention of signing with Boston next year. I do have a dream of putting my No. 11 in the rafters one day if I'm so blessed to do that. ... No disrespect to any other organizations, but here was a perfect fit,\" Irving said.\n\nMORE: Why Celtics need a healthy Kristaps Porzingis to beat Mavericks\n\nThe season did not end up being all roses the way Irving or the Celtics had hoped.\n\nIrving quickly became irritated with the situation and Boston media. He called out the lack of veteran leadership on the roster after a poor stretch to start the season in November, then specifically targeted the younger players in a postgame rant in January.\n\nBy February, Irving was already walking back his comments about wanting to re-sign in Boston.\n\n\"I'm going to do what's best for my career,\" Irving said. \"I don't owe anybody sh -- .\"\n\nAfter a rough playoff performance and second-round exit, the writing was on the wall that Irving would not be returning to the Celtics. He later admitted he had a lot going on outside of basketball -- including a death in his family -- that led to his chaotic second season in Boston.\n\nCeltics fans have still not forgiven Irving for double-crossing his preseason promise, though.\n\nIrving's time with the Celtics isn't painted very fondly, but his stats might be better than you remember.\n\nIrving was an All-Star starter in both seasons with the Celtics and made All-NBA Second Team in 2018-19.\n\nHis playoff performance was one to forget, though.\n\nAfter missing the entire 2018 NBA Playoffs with the Celtics due to injury, Irving had one of the worst postseason performances of his career in 2019. He posted playoff career lows in field goal and 3-point percentage and averaged a playoff career-high in turnovers. The Celtics swept the Pacers in the first round but were handled by the Bucks in five games in the second round.\n\nMORE: Giving new grades to Mavericks, Nets for Kyrie Irving trade\n\nAfter the 2019 NBA Playoffs, it became clear that Irving and the Celtics were not the right fit.\n\nThe star guard wasted no time to cross his statements about returning to Boston from the start of the season. On the first day of free agency, he signed a four-year, $141 million contract with the Nets to join forces with his friend, Kevin Durant.\n\nThe news of Brooklyn's new star duo was announced in one tweet from ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski.\n\nIrving remained with the Nets for three and a half seasons until he was moved to the Mavericks at the 2023 trade deadline.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8164068091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:09:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:09:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:07:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://guyanachronicle.com/2024/06/06/irving-the-most-gifted-player-the-nba-has-ever-seen-says-james/", "title": "Irving 'the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen', says James - Guyana Chronicle", "body": "KYRIE Irving is the \"most gifted player the NBA has ever seen\" and holds the key to the Dallas Mavericks' chances of victory in the NBA Finals, according to former team-mate LeBron James.\n\nJames and Irving played together with the Cleveland Cavaliers from 2014 to 2017, making the NBA Finals in each of those seasons and triumphing in 2015-16.\n\nIrving then enjoyed stints with the Boston Celtics and Brooklyn Nets before joining Dallas last February.\n\nHe has been in great form during the offseason, averaging 22.8 points and 5.2 assists as well aor their second NBA championship.\n\nSpeaking on an episode of his 'Mind the Game' podcast, James said of Irving: \"I'm so happy and so proud to watch him continue his growth.\n\n\"I would call Kyrie 'the wizard' all the time. There was nothing on a basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do.\"\n\nJames highlighted Irving's performance in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals, when he scored 24 of his 30 points in the first half against the Minnesota Timberwolves, as the standout moment of this postseason.\n\nWhile Boston may be favourites for the NBA Finals, which tip off today at TD Garden, James says Irving's ability gives Dallas a chance.\n\n\"That was like, 'oh s***, Dallas may be able to not only win the Western Conference finals, they might be able to win the whole thing',\" James said of Irving's Game 1 display.\n\n\"Because of that wild card. {"uri": "8161877506", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "22:39:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T22:39:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T22:37:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/nba-finals-mavericks-celtics-kyrie-irving-ad6baa150b21fdc3039bc90339e3fd42", "title": "The reflective side of Kyrie Irving has been front and center in playoff run with Mavs", "body": "DALLAS (AP) -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago.\n\nIt was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavs set to face the Boston Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday night.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently, stopping short of mea culpas but making clear he's learned a lot along the way.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player.\n\nThen came the COVID-19 pandemic and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, Irving asked out of Brooklyn, and he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavs point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe former No. 1 overall pick out of Duke had never been anywhere near Texas in his career but was greeted by two familiar faces. Mavs general manager Nico Harrison used to work for Nike, and coach Jason Kidd was the point guard of the then-New Jersey Nets when Irving was growing up in that area.\n\nIrving caught up with the team in Los Angeles after the trade, and the Mavericks won their first two games with him.\n\n\"You could see the smile,\" Kidd said. \"You could see the relief, or you could see that he was ready to have fun and play the game that he loves.\"\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. The first full season together was what the Mavs expected when they pulled off Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\nA late-season surge lifted the Mavs to fifth in the West, although they've been the lower seed throughout these playoffs.\n\nDallas beat the Los Angeles Clippers in six games in the first round, ousting Tyronn Lue, Irving's coach from his championship season alongside LeBron James in Cleveland in 2016.\n\n\"He's very, very patient,\" Lue said after that series of the difference between the Irving he coached and today's version. \"You couldn't get this Kyrie when I had him. He wants to kill you every moment, every second. But now you can see, he's just letting the game come to him.\"\n\nThe Mavs beat top-seeded Oklahoma City in six games before knocking out No. 3 Minnesota in five games in the Western Conference finals, the clincher giving Dallas a five-game road winning streak in the playoffs.\n\n\"I feel like it's a great chapter that's being written right now,\" Irving said. \"I'm enjoying every step of the way. I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm enjoying the hot weather right now. I'm enjoying the Dallas community. We talked about this early in the season, just how much I felt embraced.\"\n\nIrving went on to say it went deeper than that, reminding reporters of an entire career spent in the other conference.\n\n\"Seasonal depression is real when you're growing up in the north,\" Irving said. \"I spent 12 years in the Eastern Conference in three cold cities that deal with four seasons. So you come out here and you're able to get outside and ground yourself a little bit more and spend some time with your family. Watch your kids run outside.\"\n\nIrving and Doncic have at least another season together. Irving has a player option for 2025-26, Doncic for the season after that.\n\nKidd believes a preseason trip to Madrid, where Doncic grew as a teenaged pro in the EuroLeague, helped the two superstars bond.\n\nNow, winning is cementing that bond, one of the most poignant moments for the pair coming in the final seconds of Game 3 against the Timberwolves, after the Mavs knew they had clinched a 3-0 lead.\n\n\"When we were winning by nine on that last possession, I told (Irving), 'I'm tired,' and he told me, 'That's the way it's supposed to be,'\" Doncic said. \"He brought the calmness to the team and to me. He brought the maturity. I'm learning from him every day.\"\n\nThere might not have been many teammates lining up to say those things in Irving's first three stops, and the magnitude looms larger with the words coming from the face of the Dallas franchise.\n\nEven though his relationships with Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and some of his other former Boston teammates are fine, Irving believes he is a better teammate now than he was then.\n\n\"The greatest thing I learned from Boston was just being able to manage not only my emotions, but just what's going on on a day-to-day basis of being a leader of a team or being one of the leaders and having young guys around you that have their own goals,\" Irving said. \"You have to learn how to put the big picture first.\"\n\nA more introspective Irving is on the big stage again, and knows what's coming from the crowd in Boston.", "source": {"uri": "apnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AP NEWS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164326779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:06:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:06:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:04:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5544613/2024/06/06/boston-celtics-kyrie-irving-dallas-mavericks-2/", "title": "Niceties are over. Kyrie Irving's ability to 'work through' boos will be tested in Garden", "body": "BOSTON -- With Game 1 of the NBA Finals between the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks upon us, it's going to be a tough job for the bull gang at TD Garden to clear away all those rose petals being laid at Kyrie Irving's feet.\n\nOf course, Thursday night's Garden crowd will be happy to help out with that assignment. More about that in a moment. First, though, a quick summation of Nice Things Being Said About Irving, Pre-Game 1 edition:\n\n* During Wednesday's media availabilities at the Garden, Mavericks megastar Luka Don\u010di\u0107 marveled at the shots Irving takes in practice and then re-marveled at the in-game shots: \"The things he even tries in the game, it's insane,\" Don\u010di\u0107 said. \"I don't see nobody trying those shots.\"\n\n* On the Boston side, Irving's former Celtics teammate Jaylen Brown said the time they spent together \"was great\" and that he \"definitely learned a lot from Kyrie while he was here.\"\n\nAnd for those interested in a not-connected-to-the-finals observation, LeBron James has weighed in. Just the other day he called his former Cleveland Cavaliers teammate \"the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nIrving was asked about that last one, that Jamesian bouquet, when he spoke with the media Wednesday. \"Oh, God, I love it,\" Irving said, smiling. \"Got to love this, man.\"\n\nAnd yet we all know how Irving will be treated by the Garden masses Thursday night: They're going to boo and holler every time he touches the ball. And that, folks, is a reality in professional sports. Yes, booing takes many forms. Fans boo hometown heroes who are either slumping or perceived as not hustling. It happened to Red Sox legend Carl Yastrzemski back in the day, as was referenced by former Celtics coach Rick Pitino on that night in 2000 when he made his never-to-be-forgotten speech about how \"Larry Bird's not walking through that door, fans. Kevin McHale's not walking through that door, and Robert Parish is not walking through that door. And if you expect them to walk through that door, they're going to be gray and old.\"\n\nVillains? Yes, the villains get crushed. Bruins fans can help out here by citing Ulf Samuelsson and Matt Cooke for the career-altering hits they put on Cam Neely and Marc Savard.\n\nBoston fans have booed former stars who had the temerity to sign with other teams, with Johnny Damon (Red Sox) and Adam Vinatieri (Patriots) coming to mind. But it's tricky how it works sometimes: Red Sox outfielder Manny Ramirez flat-out quit playing, thus forcing a trade, and yet his returns to Fenway for various alumni events and commemorations have been met with overwhelming approval.\n\nIrving is different. That's partly because Ramirez helped deliver two championships during his Boston tenure. Irving delivered nothing. But it might also be because, if you believe what Irving is saying, it was a different Kyrie Irving who played for the Celtics. Irving, remember, was obtained for the explicit purpose of helping the Celtics to another NBA championship. A first-round pick was involved in making that happen. Irving seemed to buy in. Who'll ever forget that Hallmark special of a Nike TV commercial in which Irving is shown playing one-on-one with his dad on the sainted Garden parquet? In a voice-over, Irving says: \"He's the reason I wear No. 11. I want to be the reason no one else will.\"\n\nSo there it was, Irving putting it out there that one day his number will be up there in the Garden rafters with Bill Russell's No. 6, Larry Bird's No. 33, the Cooz's No. 14 and so on. After two seasons, no championships and a whole lot of disconnection -- such as that time he said, \"I'm going to do what's best for my career\" -- Irving decided that what was best for his career was signing with the Brooklyn Nets.\n\nThe whole thing was a mess, and Irving has been given villain status. And he's been hearing about it at the Garden ever since. Mostly it's been just that, very loud but very old-school booing, but there was also that kid who tossed a water bottle, which was silly, juvenile, reckless and, let's add, potentially dangerous.\n\nBut listening to Irving speak Wednesday, one wonders whether over the years he has ... what? Mellowed? Matured? Where are we here? Here's some of Irving from Wednesday:\n\n\"You've just got to breathe through it,\" he said, referring to the expected cascade of booing. \"To all my young'ins out there who are dealing with some of the crowd reactions and what they're saying to you, you have to breathe and realize that this is not as hostile as you think it is. I've been able to work through that and realize that some of that is anxiety and some of that is nervousness, and it can all be turned into a strength.\"\n\nThe easy takeaway there is that the louder people boo, the better Irving is going to play ... that is, turn it into a strength. The better takeaway, though, is his observation about being able to \"work through\" things and dealing with \"anxiety.\" Which brings us to something Irving said earlier in the week about his Boston days.\n\n\"I know sometimes in sports, it's literally about the end goal and result in what you accomplish, and that's one thing,\" he said. \"But we're still human. At the end of the day, I wasn't my best self during that time. When I look back on it, I just see it as a time where I learned how to let go of things and learned how to talk through my emotions.\"\n\nThere's a lot there in that one quote. There's Irving, saying he wasn't his best self during that time. There's Irving, saying he learned how to let go of things and \"talk through my emotions.\"\n\nBut he's still going to get booed in Boston on Thursday night, probably louder than ever. It is, after all, the NBA Finals, not the National Spelling Bee. And booing, when done within reason, comes with the price of the ticket. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.\n\nBut again, if you believe the words Irving is speaking now -- a big if, that one -- it means the crowd will be booing a guy who doesn't exist anymore.", {"uri": "8164725782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:03:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:03:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:03:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/06/kyrie-irving-celtics-trade-mavericks-explained", "title": "Why Kyrie Irving left the Boston Celtics, explained", "body": "If you went back in time and found yourself in the summer of 2017 right after Kyrie Irving demanded a trade from the Cleveland Cavaliers, there's no way you'd ever think you'd see that guy in anything but another green uniform for the rest of his career.\n\nThe Celtics traded Isaiah Thomas, Jae Crowder, two draft picks and some cap filler to the Cavaliers in exchange for Irving in August that summer. He seemed so thrilled after finally getting his wish to move on from the Cavaliers.\n\nREAD MORE: The Celtics gave up more in the Irving trade than any team had in years at that point\n\nAnd with the way Irving and everyone else talked about the team throughout that season, it just seemed like a foregone conclusion that he'd be a Celtic for the rest of his life.\n\nAlas. Here we are. Irving is a Dallas Maverick and will go up against his former team in the NBA Finals this year. Not only that, but people in Boston absolutely hate Irving at this point.\n\nSome of you are probably wondering how we got here. What on Earth made Kyrie decide to leave Boston? Don't you worry, folks. We got you.\n\nLet's dig into it.\n\nIrving's first year with Boston didn't go as planned\n\nIrving's first year with the Celtics was solid. Despite losing Gordon Hayward to a catastrophic leg injury, Boston was still the best team in the Eastern Conference as a 53-win team.\n\nThe injury bug bit again, though. Irving missed the end of the year because of an infection on the same knee he'd had a patellar fracture on in 2015. Despite him missing time, though, the Celtics still made a run to Game 7 of the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nIrving told fans he would stay\n\nThings got a bit tense through the summer because of Irving's refusal to sign a contract extension with the Celtics. It made sense because he'd make more money hitting the open market and re-signing in Boston, but it still had fans on edge.\n\nLeading into the season, though, he sounded committed. He even told fans and the team he planned on re-signing in Boston.\n\nHe even starred in a Nike commercial with his dad about hanging his jersey in the rafters at TD Garden someday.\n\nObviously, none of that happened because things changed.\n\nBoston's chemistry was off\n\nAs Boston got deeper into the season, it was clear there was a chemistry problem with the team. Something wasn't clicking.\n\nIrving tried to take on a leadership role with the team as one of the veteran players on the squad, but it backfired on him. He called out the young players on the team and completely lost the locker room.\n\nIrving switched up\n\nShortly after this, by February, Irving had changed his tune about re-signing with Boston. He was asked whether he'd be back and said \"Ask me July 1.\" That's a totally different tone than \"I plan on re-signing here.\"\n\nHe also met with Kevin Durant later that year at the All-Star game where Durant later admitted the two were \"solidified\" in teaming up at this point.\n\nAt this point, it was over in Boston for Irving.\n\nIrving said \"personal factors\" made him change his mind\n\nBoston flames out of the playoffs against Giannis Antetokounmpo and the Bucks. Irving signs with Brooklyn later that summer.\n\nHe was asked why he changed his mind later on in his introductory press conference with Brooklyn and explained his rationale. To make a long story short, he said some \"personal\" things were going on in his life that made him change his mind.\n\n\"Nine months ago, I was sitting in front of the Boston crowd saying that I wanted to re-sign. And after that, a lot of things happened in my personal life that really changed the landscape of how I felt about the game of basketball and actually playing it in a team environment. That really affected me as a human being. I didn't share it with anyone. I didn't want to come out and say that this is bothering me, or I'm in a depression at this point of dealing with the death of my grandfather.\n\nSo when all this happened, and the NBA and the 'pressures,' I'll put it in quotations, from this basketball game came into free agency and I was dealing with my future, I wanted to dispel all those things, but I don't think I did it in the right way of being honest about how I felt.\"\n\nThe rest is history.\n\nHere's how the Celtics and Mavericks stacked up against each other in the 2024 regular season Here's how Grant Williams could get a championship ring from the Celtics-Mavericks NBA Finals The Lakers are reportedly targeting Dan Hurley as coach and fans were stunned at the turn of events", "source": {"uri": "ftw.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "For The Win"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mike_d_sykes@ftw.usatoday.com", "name": "Mike D. {"uri": "8162189973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "04:56:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T04:56:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T04:56:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/ap/sports/the-reflective-side-of-kyrie-irving-has-been-front-and-center-in-run-to-nba/article_0d059b8f-38f2-5755-b2ec-b3eae049b1dd.html", "title": "The reflective side of Kyrie Irving has been front and center in run to NBA Finals with Mavs", "body": "DALLAS -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago.\n\nIt was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavs set to face the Boston Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday night.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently, stopping short of mea culpas but making clear he's learned a lot along the way.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player.\n\nThen came the COVID-19 pandemic and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, Irving asked out of Brooklyn, and he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavs point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe former No. 1 overall pick out of Duke had never been anywhere near Texas in his career but was greeted by two familiar faces. Mavs general manager Nico Harrison used to work for Nike, and coach Jason Kidd was the point guard of the then-New Jersey Nets when Irving was growing up in that area.\n\nIrving caught up with the team in Los Angeles after the trade, and the Mavericks won their first two games with him. \"You could see the smile,\" Kidd said. \"You could see the relief, or you could see that he was ready to have fun and play the game that he loves.\"\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. The first full season together was what the Mavs expected when they pulled off Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\nA late-season surge lifted the Mavs to fifth in the West, although they've been the lower seed throughout these playoffs.\n\nDallas beat the Los Angeles Clippers in six games in the first round, ousting Tyronn Lue, Irving's coach from his championship season alongside LeBron James in Cleveland in 2016.\n\n\"He's very, very patient,\" Lue said after that series of the difference between the Irving he coached and today's version. \"You couldn't get this Kyrie when I had him. He wants to kill you every moment, every second. But now you can see, he's just letting the game come to him.\"\n\nThe Mavs beat top-seeded Oklahoma City in six games before knocking out No. 3 Minnesota in five games in the Western Conference finals, the clincher giving Dallas a five-game road winning streak in the playoffs.\n\n\"I feel like it's a great chapter that's being written right now,\" Irving said. \"I'm enjoying every step of the way. I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm enjoying the hot weather right now. I'm enjoying the Dallas community. We talked about this early in the season, just how much I felt embraced.\"\n\nIrving went on to say it went deeper than that, reminding reporters of an entire career spent in the other conference.\n\n\"Seasonal depression is real when you're growing up in the north,\" Irving said. \"I spent 12 years in the Eastern Conference in three cold cities that deal with four seasons. So you come out here and you're able to get outside and ground yourself a little bit more and spend some time with your family. Watch your kids run outside.\"\n\nIrving and Doncic have at least another season together. Irving has a player option for 2025-26, Doncic for the season after that.\n\nKidd believes a preseason trip to Madrid, where Doncic grew as a teenaged pro in the EuroLeague, helped the two superstars bond.\n\nNow, winning is cementing that bond, one of the most poignant moments for the pair coming in the final seconds of Game 3 against the Timberwolves, after the Mavs knew they had clinched a 3-0 lead.\n\n\"When we were winning by nine on that last possession, I told (Irving), 'I'm tired,' and he told me, 'That's the way it's supposed to be,'\" Doncic said. \"He brought the calmness to the team and to me. He brought the maturity. While the Mavericks may be wary of the formidable duo of Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum, the Celtics' Jrue Holiday has expressed great concern about the Mavericks' guard, Kyrie Irving.\n\nDuring a recent press conference, Holiday was asked about his team's strategy to stop Irving. Without hesitation, he responded with one word: \"Pray.\"\n\nThe eight-time All-Star has often left opponents scrambling to devise effective strategies against him on the court. His move to the Mavericks has amplified his potential to disrupt defensive plans with his improved athleticism and seasoned play.\n\nIn this year's two regular-season games against Boston, Kobe Bryant's mentee averaged 21 points and 2.5 assists, shooting 42 percent from the field.\n\nMoreover, Irving averaged 27.0 points, 4.6 assists, and 3.6 rebounds in the five-game series win over the Minnesota Timberwolves.\n\nDespite being a dominant force in recent seasons, the Celtics have yet to clinch the championship. Their powerful duo, Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum, have consistently driven the team to the playoffs but have fallen short of the ultimate prize.\n\nJrue Holiday recognizes that Kyrie Irving is not just a standout player during the regular season or playoffs. {"uri": "8161585375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:57:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:57:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:56:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/04/sports/why-do-celtics-fans-boo-kyrie-irving-recapping-his-tumultuous-history-with-boston/", "title": "Why do Celtics fans boo Kyrie Irving? Recapping his tumultuous history with Boston - The Boston Globe", "body": "RelatedWe know what Boston thinks of Kyrie Irving. But in Dallas, they couldn't be more thrilled with their star.\n\nEven though Irving has largely deflected comments regarding his rocky tenure in Boston -- an approach shared by many of his former Celtics teammates -- it's all but a given Irving will be booed profusely as soon as he steps on the parquet floor for Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday night.\n\nSo why is Irving held in contempt by Boston sports fans?\n\nLet's run through the timeline of Irving's eventful two years with the Celtics.\n\nAfter the Isaiah Thomas-led Celtics put together a few spirited runs, Danny Ainge orchestrated a blockbuster move to bring in an elite talent in Irving during the 2017 offseason.\n\nBoston dealt away Thomas, Jae Crowder, Ante Zizic, and Brooklyn's 2018 unprotected first-round pick for Irving, with the skilled guard expected to be the featured piece on a Celtics roster that already featured Al Horford and signed Gordon Hayward in free agency.\n\nAdd in a stacked cast of younger talent in rookie Jayson Tatum, 20-year-old Jaylen Brown, 23-year-old Marcus Smart, and 23-year-old Terry Rozier, and Boston was seemingly set for the long haul with Irving leading the charge.\n\n\"I'm grateful and I can't wait to get on the floor,\" Irving said at his introductory press conference at TD Garden. \"Boston came right at the exact time and it was meant to be that way.\"\n\nIrving and the Celtics put together a successful first season, with Irving averaging 24.4 points per game and Boston finishing second in the Eastern Conference with a 55-27 record.\n\nBy the time the playoffs rolled around, the Celtics had to trudge ahead without Irving (knee surgery) and Hayward (fractured ankle, dislocated ankle).\n\nBut the shorthanded Boston roster reeled off an impressive run, forcing LeBron James and the Cavaliers into a decisive Game 7 in the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nBoston's run came to an end, with the Celtics falling to Cleveland, 87-79.\n\nIrving was not in attendance for Game 7, as he was recovering from nasal surgery.\n\n\"Kyrie had a deviated septum, had some surgery on that, and so I don't think he wanted to be seen,\" Ainge noted, adding: \"He's a really good-looking guy. He can't ruin his movie career.\"\n\nThings quickly went downhill for a Celtics team that seemed poised for a breakthrough season in 2018-19.\n\nAll eyes were fixated on a now-healthy Irving entering the 2018-19 season, especially with the skilled scorer entering the last year of his contract.\n\nBut Irving assuaged any fears felt by Celtics fans during an event with season ticket holders at TD Garden, declaring he planned to stay in Boston for the long haul.\n\n\"I shared it with some of my teammates as well as the organization and everyone else in Boston: If you guys will have me back, I plan on re-signing here next year,\" Irving said to a cheering crowd at TD Garden.\n\nThe following day, Irving elaborated on why he pledged a commitment to staying in Boston.\n\n\"I needed just some time to kind of be back in Boston and feel great about different things I wanted to explore in my career,\" Irving said. \"But I think the important thing was just being happy and having an environment where I'm challenged on a physical level as well as mental.\"\n\nIt didn't take long for Irving's stint in Boston to sour.\n\nAfter a 105-103 road loss to the Magic on Jan. 14, Irving appeared to vent his frustrations about the Celtics' younger core and their missteps on the court.\n\n\"What's the big picture? What are we doing here?\" Irving said. \"These are things I don't think some of my teammates have faced just every single day. It's not easy to be great.\"\n\nCeltics fans continued to feel uneasy about Irving's future in Boston after a video surfaced of the guard chatting with then-Warriors forward Kevin Durant during the 2019 NBA All-Star Game.\n\nAmid fears that Irving and Durant were planning on teaming up on a team with two max slots to take in both of their new contracts, Irving sparred with reporters over the video.\n\n\"What I do with my life is my business,\" Irving said, per NBC Sports Boston. \"It's none of yours, none of anybody's business.\"\n\nDurant admitted in 2020 that both he and Irving formulated their plan to team up the following offseason during that All-Star Game meet-up.\n\n\"The All-Star game video where they caught us in the hallway. That's when it was solidified that we were going somewhere,\" Durant said during \"The ETC's\" podcast in 2020. \"They didn't know for a fact where it was, but it was somewhere.\"\n\nThe 2018-19 Celtics season came to an end against the Bucks in the Eastern Conference Semifinals, with Irving struggling mightily in the five-game series.\n\nWith one foot potentially out the door when it came to Irving's tenure in Boston, the guard averaged 20.4 points per game against the Bucks -- but shot just 35.6 percent from the field, including 21.9 percent from 3-point range.\n\nIn Boston's season-ending loss in Game 5, Irving shot 6-of-21 from the field with one assist, one rebound, three turnovers and was a minus-25 in a 25-point loss to Milwaukee.\n\nSure enough, Irving went on to leave the Celtics in free agency -- teaming up with Durant and signing a four-year, $141 million with the Brooklyn Nets.\n\nAfter missing his first game back at TD Garden in 2019-20 due to injury, Irving drew headlines for his unique pregame ritual before playing on the parquet floor for the first time as a member of the Nets.\n\nPrior to pregame warmups, Irving was spotted waving sage around the floor at TD Garden.\n\n\"It just comes from a lot of native tribes,\" Irving said after the game, per CBS Sports. \"Being able to sage, just cleanse the energy, make sure that we're all balanced. When we come into this job, we come into this place, it's not anything that I don't do at home that I did today. I saged last game, and I plan to sage almost every game if the opposing team will allow me to.\"\n\nIrving's first playoff series against the Celtics after signing with the Nets had several ugly incidents, with a fan throwing a water bottle at Irving's head after Brooklyn's 141-126 win in Game 4 of their first-round bout.\n\n\"It's been that way in history in terms of entertainers, performers, and sports for a very long time, just underlying racism and treating people like they're in a human zoo,\" Irving said. \"Throwing stuff at people, saying things. There's a certain point where it gets to be too much.\"\n\nJust before avoiding that water bottle, Irving appeared to stomp on the Celtics' logo at midcourt -- dragging his shoe across Lucky the Leprechaun's face before making his way off the court.\n\nThe Celtics took care of business against the Nets in their rematch, sweeping them in four games in an anticipated first-round matchup.\n\nGame 1 of that series saw Celtics fans continually get under Irving's skin, with multiple boos and jeers eventually prompting Irving to toss up the middle finger to the TD Garden crowd. He was later fined $50,000 by the NBA for the gesture.\n\nThat series marked the most recent time that Irving battled the Celtics in the playoffs, with the guard eventually being traded to the Mavericks in February 2023.\n\nMore than a year later, Irving will try to topple the Celtics in the 2024 NBA Finals -- with Banner 18 hanging in the balance.\n\n\"I'm built for these moments, to be able to handle circumstances like that, and I've been able to grow since then,\" Irving said on Monday. \"So of course it's going to be a hectic environment, but I'm looking forward to it and I see it as a healthy relationship that I have with the fans.\n\n\"I almost think about 'Gladiator,' just winning the crowd over. It is good to hear the TD Garden silent when you're playing well. They still respect great basketball.\"", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8163543318", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:31:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:31:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:31:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/kyrie-irving-boston-fans-celtics-mavericks-nba-finals/", "title": "Kyrie Irving ready to just \"breathe through it\" when Celtics fans get on him during NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- Kyrie Irving was welcomed into TD Garden on Wednesday for media day ahead of the NBA Finals. It won't be as cordial for the Mavs guard once Celtics fans pack the Garden for Game 1 on Thursday night.\n\nIrving's return to Boston to battle the Celtics for a championship has been one of the biggest storylines leading up to the NBA Finals. And with over a week of downtime before the two teams square off in Game 1, there was a lot made of Irving's past history with the Celtics.\n\nThere's no need to rehash Irving's departure from Boston and all the incidents that followed, but it got ugly at times. Real ugly. Irving expressed some remorse over all of it earlier this week, likely in a way to get on the good side of Boston fans ahead the series.\n\nBut he's seen both sides of Celtics fans and he knows which side will be out during the NBA Finals. He's promising a much better response than the last time he was at TD Garden for a playoff game.\n\n\"I mean, I've experienced Boston twofold; my first few years being in the NBA playing for the Cavs, then coming here to Boston, then being right down the street in Brooklyn, now being here in the Finals playing against them in a potential four-to-seven-game series,\" Irving said during Wednesday's media day.\n\n\"You just got to breathe through it. To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions, what they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is,\" he continued. \"Don't overthink it. I've been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness. It could all be turned into a strength.\n\n\"There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball,\" Irving added. \"The fans are going to say what they're going to say. I appreciate them and their relationship they have to the game. But it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nSo it doesn't sound like there will be any more logo stomping or freedom rocket salutes from Irving, but we'll believe it when we don't see it. Celtics fans are going to do everything they can to get Irving off his game and into his head.\n\nAs for the game itself, the Celtics will be looking to limit both Irving and his backcourt mate, Luka Doncic. It's going to be an arduous task for Boston defenders, but one the Celtics are confident they can handle.\n\nHoliday is one of the best defenders in the game, and he's got plenty of experience to draw on when it comes to keeping Irving in check.\n\n\"I think it's just familiarity. I think knowing each other's game, doing your best to stay in front of him, trying to take away the things that will probably hurt you the most,\" said Holiday, who has racked up six All-Defensive honors throughout his career.\n\nBut keeping Irving and Doncic from going wild on the scoresheet -- or at least trying to -- will not fall on the shoulders of just one player.\n\n\"Probably most [important] of all is having help,\" said Holiday. \"Him being able to see multiple guys on the court, making it look like it's crowded, making shots as tough as possible, even though he's a tough shot-maker.\"\n\n\"They're two of the most talented guards this league has seen. It's going to be a challenge for all of us. It's not going to be one-on-one; we all have to participate,\" said Derrick White. \"It's going to be a lot of fun. Just have to embrace that challenge.\"\n\nWhile the Celtics have to worry about the Doncic-Irving duo, the Mavs will have their hands full with Boston's dynamic duet of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. (Not to mention Holiday, White, and Kristaps Porzingis, all of whom can make a team pay on the offensive end.) Irving was teammates when Tatum and Brown during their first seasons in the league, and is amazed by their growth over the years.\n\n\"I'm excited. They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point,\" Irving said. \"So I'm proud of them. I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"", "source": {"uri": The previous two series were both in the first round, however -- in 2021 and 2022 when Irving was with the Brooklyn Nets -- and now he'll be battling his former team on the NBA Finals stage.\n\nConsidering Irving's tumultuous history in Boston, he'll likely receive a chorus of boos from Celtics fans in Thursday's Game 1. But whereas he returned the crowd's hostility in years past, the 32-year-old suggested he'll be taking a more mindful approach this time around.\n\n\"I've experienced Boston in twofold: my first few years being in the NBA playing for the Cavs, then coming here to Boston, and then being right down the street in Brooklyn, and then now being here in the Finals playing against them, in a potential four-to-seven game series,\" Irving told reporters Wednesday at NBA Finals Media Day at TD Garden, as seen in the video player above.\n\n\"You've just got to breathe through it. To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions and what they're saying to you, you have to breathe and realize that this is not as hostile as you think it is. Don't overthink it.\n\n\"I've been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness and it can all be turned into a strength.\"\n\nCeltics fans may have something to say about Irving suggesting the Garden isn't as hostile as we think it is, but the veteran guard does appear to be in a different place than he was two years ago. Irving recently expressed remorse for giving the middle finger to Celtics fans during the 2022 playoffs and said Wednesday he'll keep his focus between the lines during the Finals.\n\n\"There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball,\" Irving said. \"The fans are gonna say what they're gonna say. I appreciate them and the relationship they have to the game, but it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nThe Boston backstory aside, Irving could play a crucial role in this series. He averaged 27 points per game in the Western Conference Finals -- including a 36-point effort in Dallas' decisive Game 5 victory -- and is capable of taking the game over offensively if the Celtics devote too much attention to Luka Doncic.\n\nWhether Irving can keep that momentum going against his former team remains to be seen, but at the very least, the player who quit on the Celtics in the {"uri": "8163512585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:02:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:02:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:02:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/got-love-kyrie-irving-talks-195220577.html", "title": "'Got to love this': Kyrie Irving talks LeBron James relationship ahead of 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON - The LeBron James-Kyrie Irving mutual admiration party continued Wednesday.\n\nOne day after James offered effusive praise of Irving, calling him of the most skilled players to play in the NBA and wishing he still played alongside his former teammate, Irving, the Mavs star guard playing in his fourth NBA Finals, responded.\n\n\"Got to love this, man,\" Irving said. \"I have a great reaction. It's appreciated. There's a lot of gratitude there, as well. Obviously, I'm in a different age, different place in my life. So is he. I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\n\n\"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger. Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\"\n\nIrving requested a trade from Cleveland after the Cavaliers played in their third consecutive NBA Finals in 2017. The decision to leave was stunning, considering the Cavaliers were still a championship-caliber team.\n\nIrving ended up in Boston, Dallas' opponent in this season's Finals.\n\n\"Just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table,\" Irving said. \"His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I'm appreciative for the rest of my life.\n\n\"Man, when he says comments like that, I think back to us having those moments where we're down in a series, up in a series, we're really demanding greatness from each other. Off the court, our families meshing well.\"\n\nThe Cavaliers won the 2016 championship with James and Irving leading the way. Irving made the winning shot in Game 7 against Golden State, and James had the block that helped ensure the victory.\n\nIrving is a major reason why the Mavs reached the Finals.\n\n\"I feel like I've been built for this moment because I've gone through some of the things I've gone through in my past with some of the guys that have transcended the game.\" he said, adding, \"Shoutout to LeBron for that. Knows how to stir up a media storm, get everybody in here talking about us.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "NBA Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Basketball_Association", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "National Basketball Association"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Cleveland Cavaliers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Cleveland"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Cleveland"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Dallas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Dallas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Golden State Warriors"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Recreation", "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Recreation", "wgt": 9}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Relationships/Advice", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Online_Writing/Drama", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Online Writing/Drama", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Dice/Fill_or_Bust", "label": "dmoz/Games/Dice/Fill or Bust", "wgt": 10}], "image": "https://s.yimg.com/cv/apiv2/social/images/yahoo_default_logo-1200x1200.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9624468", "eventUri": "eng-9624468", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.4901960784313726, "wgt": 178, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8163290658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:53:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:53:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:52:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/nba-finals-2024-mavericks-celtics-rcna154974", "title": "NBA Finals preview: Biggest storylines to watch in Mavericks vs. Celtics", "body": "The NBA Finals will tip off Thursday night with the Boston Celtics hosting the Dallas Mavericks, a matchup pitting two of the league's top duos against one another.\n\nDallas is led by a backcourt of the do-everything Slovenian guard Luka Doncic and resurgent eight-time All-Star Kyrie Irving. Boston uses the incredible versatility of Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum, two young stars entering their prime.\n\nWho has the edge heading into Game 1? Let's break down the biggest storylines.\n\nThe Celtics (64-18) were arguably the most well-rounded team in the NBA this season. They finished with an offensive rating of 123.2, not only the best in the league but in league history. Boston's defense wasn't shabby either, ending the regular season with a 111.6 rating, third best in the NBA.\n\nTatum has been the catalyst all season for the Celtics, but particularly in the postseason. He leads the team in points (26), rebounds (10.4) and assists (5.9) per game. Brown is just a notch behind him statistically, averaging 25 points, 6.1 rebounds and 2.6 assists a game. He earned Eastern Conference Finals MVP following Boston's sweep of the Indiana Pacers after making big play after big play, either as a scorer or facilitator.\n\nThe X factor for this series could be guard Jrue Holiday, a veteran acquired last offseason in a trade with the Portland Trail Blazers. Boston gave up a lot to get him -- Malcolm Brogdon, Robert Williams and two first-round picks -- but he's been worth it.\n\nHoliday, who won an NBA title with the Milwaukee Bucks in 2021, is averaging 12.7 points and 4.6 assists in the playoffs while playing his typical lockdown defense. How Holiday guards Irving could determine whether the Celtics claim the NBA championship for a league-leading 18th time.\n\nSpeaking of which...\n\nThe Mavericks' 32-year-old point guard didn't have the best time in a Celtics uniform, to say the least. In fact, he's known as one of the biggest villains of Boston's fan base. Irving played two seasons in Boston, from 2017-2019, averaging 24.1 points and 6.1 assists a game, and led the franchise to the Eastern Conference Finals in 2018.\n\nHowever the following season he struggled mightily in the 2019 playoffs, most notably in the Eastern Conference semifinals against Milwaukee. Irving shot a dreadful 37 for 104 from the field and 7 for 32 from 3-point range as the Celtics were eliminated in five games.\n\nHe wasn't much better off the court.\n\nIrving told fans at a season-ticket holder event ahead of the 2018-19 season that he planned on re-signing with the franchise. The next February, when asked if he was set to return to Boston, he famously said, \"I don't owe anybody s---.\" After the season he left to join Kevin Durant and the Brooklyn Nets.\n\nThis will be Irving's third playoff series since leaving Boston.\n\nHe told members of the media this week after practice that he is a changed man.\n\n\"I'm built for these moments, to be able to handle circumstances like that, and I've been able to grow since then,\" he said. \"So of course it's going to be a hectic environment, but I'm looking forward to it and I see it as a healthy relationship that I have with the fans. I almost think about 'Gladiator,' just winning the crowd over. It is good to hear the TD Garden silent when you're playing well. They still respect great basketball.\"\n\nAnd great basketball is exactly what Irving is playing.\n\nIrving averaged 25.6 points, 5.2 assists and 5 rebounds per game for the Mavericks (50-42) during the regular season, but he has stepped up his production in the playoffs. In the Western Conference Finals against the Minnesota Timberwolves, he poured in 27 points a night on 49 percent shooting from the field. This includes a 36-point performance on 14-of-27 shooting in Game 5 that sent Dallas to the NBA Finals.\n\nLos Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James, who along with Irving brought a championship back to Cleveland in 2016, said the guard is unlike any teammate he's had in his career.\n\n\"To have a guy like Kyrie Irving as the ultimate wild card,\" James said on his \"Mind The Game\" podcast this week. \"That's like having a 'draw four' in your hand every time someone deals you cards in Uno.\"\n\nIrving complemented James earlier in his career. Now he has Doncic.\n\nSince entering the league in 2018, Doncic has been utterly dominant offensively. The 25-year-old led the NBA in scoring (33.9 points per game this season) and was second in assists (9.8). Like Irving, Doncic has continued his tear in the postseason. He sliced through Minnesota in the Western Conference Finals with an array of moves and shooting from every spot on the floor, averaging 32.4 points a game in the series.\n\nFormer NBA coach and broadcaster Stan Van Gundy publicly called Irving and Doncic the \"best offensive backcourt in the history of the NBA.\"\n\nHe might just be right.\n\nPorzingis, who spent three seasons in Dallas, from 2019-2022, is expected to return from a calf injury just in time to face his former team. The 7-foot Celtics center has not appeared in a game since April 29 in Boston's opening-round series against the Miami Heat.\n\nWhile Porzingis' services haven't truly been needed -- the Celtics went 9-1 in his absence -- he will add another dynamic piece to pair with Brown and Tatum. Porzingis is a great finisher around the rim and despite his size can hit shots from both midrange and beyond the arc.\n\nHe's also expected to bolster Boston's defense by blocking or altering shots. Porzingis swatted nearly two attempts a game this season.\n\n\"He does a great job of just making things difficult,\" Celtics guard Derrick White said at practice this week. \"It's always nice to know that he's back there, whether he blocks or he doesn't block. He makes them think about it. That's been really great having him on our side, just doing the things he did day in and day out. Once he comes back and gets in the flow, I think it's going to be nice.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-381086639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:53:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:53:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:22:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/mavericks-news-why-dallas-took-risk-on-kyrie-irving-trade-despite-controversies", "title": "Why Mavericks took risk on Kyrie Irving trade despite controversies", "body": "With the Mavericks only four wins away from a championship, it's safe to say that their risky trade for Kyrie Irving was a rousing success.\n\nKyrie Irving endured plenty of low points during his time as a member of the Brooklyn Nets. His decision to join the the Nets in 2019 was met with celebration, but four years later, his mere presence gave the Nets franchise consternation. During the 2022-23 season, the Nets reached its last straw with Irving following a controversial tweet, and the veteran guard eventually asked for a trade. It was the Dallas Mavericks that swooped him and acquired him, but it did not come without its fair share of risks.\n\nHowever, the Mavericks' decision to take a chance on Irving has paid off in a big way just a year later. The Mavs are four wins away from hoisting the Larry O'Brien trophy for the second time in franchise history, thanks in large part to Irving. As a famous general manager once said, \"scared money don't make none\" and the Mavs are certainly thankful that they took a leap of faith in bringing Irving in, with franchise president Nico Harrison banking on his relationship with Irving to serve as a catalyst for the talented guard's much-needed blank slate.\n\n\"Honestly, (the confidence) was just the fact that I know Kyrie. I know his character, and I know how talented he is,\" Harrison said, per Sam Amick of The Athletic.\n\nIt wasn't like the Mavericks had to break the bank to bring Kyrie Irving on board. The Mavs traded Spencer Dinwiddie, Dorian Finney-Smith, an unprotected 2029 first-round pick (as well as two second-rounders) to the Nets in exchange for Irving and Markieff Morris; it's safe to say that Dinwiddie and Finney-Smith, while important pieces during the Mavs' run to the Conference Finals in 2022, don't even come close to the talent that is Irving.\n\nThus, given Harrison's familiarity with Irving during their days working together with Nike, the Mavericks saw a golden opportunity to buy low. Even in free agency, the Mavs were able to sign Irving to a less expensive contract than what it took for the Houston Rockets to bring Fred VanVleet in.\n\n\"You can't just get talent like (Irving). It's not out there. Think of how many guys in the league who are available that are that talented. It just doesn't happen. So we were fortunate that Kyrie became available. For me, I didn't listen to the outside noise because I have my own relationship with him,\" Harrison added.\n\nThrough Kyrie Irving's one and a half-year stint thus far with the Mavericks, he has been a model professional whom his teammates have looked up to. Irving has emerged as the team's vocal leader, as well as an assassin the team can get behind in the clutch. Even the Mavs would say that the trade worked out better than they had envisioned, especially given how deep in the gutter nearly everyone's perception of Irving was at the time.\n\nThe Mavericks took a big risk in bringing Kyrie Irving in after a tumultuous stint with the Nets\n\n2021 was when disaster began for Kyrie Irving in a Nets uniform. Irving sustained an injury that kept him out of the Nets' second-round defeat at the hands of the Milwaukee Bucks, and from there, it only went downhill. Prior to the start of the 2021-22 season, the city of New York required athletes playing for a team based in the city to take the COVID-19 vaccine.\n\nIrving decided not to take the vaccine, and as a result, the Nets franchise decided not to play him altogether at the start of the season even though he could have suited up for the team on the road in cities not requiring vaccination. When the Nets were faltering in the middle of the season, that was when they brought Irving back to play road games, and later on, the city lifted vaccination restrictions, paving the way for Irving to suit up for home games as well.\n\nThat was when the relationship between Kyrie Irving and the Nets franchise began to crumble completely. His controversial tweet in 2022 led to an indefinite suspension, further fracturing the relationship between the two parties. So even though the Nets recovered upon Irving's return, even going on a 12-game winning streak from December 7, 2022 to January 2, 2023, the talented but polarizing guard requested a trade not too long after.\n\nAt first, it looked like the trade was going to be a disaster, what with their struggles following the 2023 trade deadline that led to their decision to tank their final few games just so they could keep their lottery pick. They then proceeded to build a group of hard-nosed defenders and competitors around Irving and Luka Doncic, and they went all-in on their core with their trades for PJ Washington and Daniel Gafford back in February.\n\nBut without the Mavericks doing nothing but provide a safe haven for Irving to be his unabashed self, they won't be able to reach this point. Welcomed and beloved with open arms, the 32-year old guard has elevated the Luka Doncic-led team and has helped them to within four wins away from a championship in return. And it all started with the Mavs' decision to block out the noise and accept Irving for who he is.\n\n\"I think we had to look past the noise. Like, we're talking about Kai the basketball player. The noise is the noise. It could be good noise, bad noise, but you just have to look at what you feel fits on the floor. And that's all I think we looked at,\" Kidd said.\n\nMinority owner Mark Cuban, who was still the Mavericks' majority stakeholder at the time of the Kyrie Irving trade, echoed the same sentiment.\n\n\"You know, in this business -- and every business, really -- you've got to just block out all the social media experts and just go with who you are. Yeah, (the noise around Irving) was different. But that's the easiest stuff to block out. When they talk about someone's personality, or this and that, and then you see Kai and how he interacts with players from around the league, everybody loved him.\"", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jedd_pagaduan@clutchpoints.com", "name": "Jedd Pagaduan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Dallas Mavericks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrie_Irving", "type": "person",
