When it comes to Celtics, he earned the wrath.", "body": "DALLAS -- Of the notables who have come and gone from Boston, that city hates Dallas Mavericks guard Kyrie Irving almost as much as it despised King George III, General Charles Cornwallis and Benedict Arnold.\n\nIrving squeezed 20 years of drama in his two seasons in Boston, and Celtics fans have long memories of Irving's \"exciting\" tenure.\n\nIrving and the Mavericks will play the Boston Celtics in Game 1 of the NBA Finals Thursday night in Boston.\n\nIrving is braced for Boston's \"best,\" which if you know anything about the history of that city and its sports teams it can be the worst. Much like Philadelphia and New York, Boston is one of those towns that relishes its \"horrible\" reputation.\n\nHowever bad Irving thinks he might hear it from the Boston fans, the standard for players in his situation is the \"Ralph Sampson Treatment.\"\n\nIn the 1986 NBA Finals between Boston and Houston, Rockets center Ralph Sampson got into a fight in Game 5 with Celtics guard Jerry Sichting. The series returned to the Boston Garden for Game 6, and Celtics fans were primed for Sampson.\n\nFans wore T-shirts that read, \" \"Ralph Sampson is a sissy.\" That was not the worst of it. From the second deck, fans hung a mannequin with Sampson's name and jersey number.\n\nIrving will not get that, but this will not be some love fest.\n\nAs much as Irving has matured, evolved and changed since he left Boston in the summer of 2019, even his biggest defenders have to admit some of this is on him. You can still be a fan and a supporter of someone while acknowledging their role in the disintegration of a relationship.\n\nOn Monday after the conclusion of the Mavs' practice, Irving spoke candidly and eloquently to the media for about 20 minutes. The man can talk. {"uri": "8161801030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "21:12:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T21:12:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T21:11:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://dailyknicks.com/posts/superstar-point-guard-2017-trade-wishlist-surprisingly-included-knicks-kyrie-irving", "title": "Superstar point guard's 2017 trade wishlist surprisingly included Knicks", "body": "In 2016-17, the New York Knicks posted a 31-51 record and missed the playoffs for the fourth straight year. Another disappointing season didn't keep one of the NBA's top point guards from listing the team on his trade wishlist, though.\n\nIronically enough, the Cavaliers finished with a 51-31 record that same season, the exact opposite of the Knicks. Cleveland made it to the NBA Finals for the third straight year but came up short to Golden State. Kyrie Irving averaged a then career-high 25.2 points per game on 47.3% shooting from the field and 40.1% from three. Behind LeBron James (26.4 points per game), Irving was the team's second-leading scorer.\n\nEven with that success, 2016-17 was Irving's final season with the Cavaliers. A fallout with LeBron contributed to the point guard requesting a trade that offseason. Irving has since said he regrets how things ended, especially because Cleveland could've won another title (or more) with that duo.\n\nIrving was eventually dealt to the Celtics, although they weren't on his trade destination list. Yahoo Sports' Jake Fischer recently reported that the Knicks, Spurs, Timberwolves, and Heat were the teams the point guard wanted to go to. His agent told Cleveland that he didn't want to go to Boston.\n\nBelieve it or not, but in 2017, Irving seemingly would've been happy with a trade to New York. Maybe the front office wouldn't have traded Carmelo Anthony to Oklahoma City that September if the Knicks traded for Kyrie. How different would things have been?\n\nIrving's stint in Boston didn't go as planned, so much so that the Knicks and Celtics engaged in trade talks in 2019 that would've sent Kristaps Porzingis to Boston and Irving to New York. Irving could've been a Knick on two occasions before 2019 free agency. It's bewildering that he chose Brooklyn over New York when he had the choice. Look how that worked out for him.\n\nAfter a couple of unsuccessful stops, Kyrie has found a home in Dallas. He's returning to the NBA Finals for the first time since 2017 when he was in Cleveland. Would he have ended New York's finals drought if he had been traded there in 2017? Or if he had signed in 2019? Eh, probably not.\n\nThings worked out for the best; if the Knicks had gotten Kyrie, they might not have signed Jalen Brunson in 2022.", "source": {"uri": "dailyknicks.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-380191213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:12:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:12:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-06-05/nba-finals-notebook-porzingis-a-go-kyrie-and-lebron-make-nice-hardaway-jr-throws-shade-at-dad", "title": "NBA Finals Notebook: Porzingis a Go, Kyrie and LeBron Make Nice, Hardaway Jr. Throws Shade at Dad", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- Celtics 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis said he will be ready to \"just go out there and hoop\" for Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday night after missing Boston's last 10 games with a strained left calf.\n\n\"It was a long road to get to this point for me. But feeling good,\" he said at media day on Wednesday. \"(It) burns inside of me, not being able to be out there. But tomorrow finally I'll get the chance and I'm excited.\"\n\nPorzingis said he couldn't predict how it will be once he gets into a game for the first time since April 29.\n\n\"I did as much as I could to prepare for this moment, but there's nothing like game minutes and game experience that I'm going to get tomorrow,\" he said. \"It will be tough to jump into the finals like this.\"\n\nAn offseason acquisition that helped solidify the Celtics frontcourt, Porzingis averaged 20 points, 7.2 rebounds and almost two blocks per game. But he was again dogged by injuries that limited him to 57 games.\n\nHe left Game 4 of the first-round series against the Miami Heat and missed all of the next two rounds, when Boston eliminated Cleveland in five games and swept the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n\"Guys so far have been playing great, taking care of business, guys stepping up,\" he said, singling out Al Horford's work at center in his absence. \"I just look forward to add more to complete the mission.\"\n\nKYRIE AND LEBRON\n\nLeBron James praised former teammate Kyrie Irving on a podcast, calling him \"the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nThe feeling is mutual.\n\n\"There's a lot of gratitude there, as well,\" Irving said on Wednesday when asked if he had heard James' comments. \"I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\"\n\nJames said on his podcast \"Mind the Game\" that he's happy and proud to watch Irving in the finals, but at the same time he's \"mad that I'm not his running mate anymore.\"\n\n\"There was nothing on a basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do,\" he said.\n\nIrving and James reached the finals three straight seasons with the Cavaliers, winning it all in 2016 and losing to the Warriors the following year. Then Irving requested a trade, and the relationship soured.\n\n\"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger,\" Irving said at NBA Finals media day on Wednesday. \"Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\n\n\"(I) definitely miss him,\" Irving said. \"Just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table. His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I'm appreciative for the rest of my life.\"\n\nIrving wound up in Boston, where he also had a still-festering fallout. In previous trips back to the Garden, he has been received rudely and a similar welcome is expected for Game 1 on Thursday night.\n\nTRASH-TALKING TIM\n\nTim Hardaway Jr. couldn't resist the chance to talk trash about his father.\n\nAsked on Wednesday what it meant for him to be playing in the NBA Finals for the first time, Hardaway said, \"It means a lot. Especially being the first of my family to do so.\" Reporters chuckled and gasped.\n\nHardaway's father was a five-time All-Star in 13 NBA seasons and was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2022. He finished in the top 10 of the NBA MVP voting three times, and also won a gold medal at the 2000 Olympics.\n\nBut he only made it as far as the conference finals once, losing with the Miami Heat to Michael Jordan's Bulls in 1997.\n\nHardaway Jr. has never averaged 20 points in a season, like his father did five times, and his award votes have come mostly as a sixth man. But he said he had the advantage of his father's experience.\n\n\"I wouldn't get to this point without my dad,\" he said. \"He's always by my side. He's always a phone call away. He's always supporting me, always coming to the games. He's a phone call away when I'm struggling, when I'm not, even if I'm having great games in a stretch, he's telling me to keep my head down, don't stop, keep that energy, keep that flow going. And, he's always reiterating to me: always have fun. He's been telling me that since high school, and that's what I've been trying to do my whole entire career.\n\n\"The guy has lived it and done it. So, you know, that's that's that's the luxury I do have of having a father that played in this league.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": But feeling good,\" he said at media day on Wednesday. \"(It) burns inside of me, not being able to be out there. But tomorrow finally I'll get the chance and I'm excited.\"\n\nPorzingis said he couldn't predict how it will be once he gets into a game for the first time since April 29.\n\n\"I did as much as I could to prepare for this moment, but there's nothing like game minutes and game experience that I'm going to get tomorrow,\" he said. \"It will be tough to jump into the finals like this.\"\n\nAn offseason acquisition that helped solidify the Celtics frontcourt, Porzingis averaged 20 points, 7.2 rebounds and almost two blocks per game. But he was again dogged by injuries that limited him to 57 games.\n\nHe left Game 4 of the first-round series against the Miami Heat and missed all of the next two rounds, when Boston eliminated Cleveland in five games and swept the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n\"Guys so far have been playing great, taking care of business, guys stepping up,\" he said, singling out Al Horford's work at center in his absence. \"I just look forward to add more to complete the mission.\"\n\nKYRIE AND LEBRON\n\nLeBron James praised former teammate Kyrie Irving on a podcast, calling him \"the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nThe feeling is mutual.\n\n\"There's a lot of gratitude there, as well,\" Irving said on Wednesday when asked if he had heard James' comments. \"I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\"\n\nJames said on his podcast \"Mind the Game\" that he's happy and proud to watch Irving in the finals, but at the same time he's \"mad that I'm not his running mate anymore.\"\n\n\"There was nothing on a basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do,\" he said.\n\nIrving and James reached the finals three straight seasons with the Cavaliers, winning it all in 2016 and losing to the Warriors the following year. Then Irving requested a trade, and the relationship soured.\n\n\"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger,\" Irving said at NBA Finals media day on Wednesday. \"Now that I'm able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I'm coming from, I feel like our relationship's different because of that now.\n\n\"(I) definitely miss him,\" Irving said. \"Just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table. His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I'm appreciative for the rest of my life.\"\n\nIrving wound up in Boston, where he also had a still-festering fallout. In previous trips back to the Garden, he has been received rudely and a similar welcome is expected for Game 1 on Thursday night.\n\nTRASH-TALKING TIM\n\nTim Hardaway Jr. couldn't resist the chance to talk trash about his father.\n\nAsked on Wednesday what it meant for him to be playing in the NBA Finals for the first time, Hardaway said, \"It means a lot. Especially being the first of my family to do so.\" Reporters chuckled and gasped.\n\nHardaway's father was a five-time All-Star in 13 NBA seasons and was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2022. He finished in the top 10 of the NBA MVP voting three times, and also won a gold medal at the 2000 Olympics.\n\nBut he only made it as far as the conference finals once, losing with the Miami Heat to Michael Jordan's Bulls in 1997.\n\nHardaway Jr. has never averaged 20 points in a season, like his father did five times, and his award votes have come mostly as a sixth man. But he said he had the advantage of his father's experience.\n\n\"I wouldn't get to this point without my dad,\" he said. \"He's always by my side. He's always a phone call away. He's always supporting me, always coming to the games. He's a phone call away when I'm struggling, when I'm not, even if I'm having great games in a stretch, he's telling me to keep my head down, don't stop, keep that energy, keep that flow going. And, he's always reiterating to me: always have fun. He's been telling me that since high school, and that's what I've been trying to do my whole entire career.\n\n\"The guy has lived it and done it. So, you know, that's that's that's the luxury I do have of having a father that played in this league.\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8163226460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:07:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:07:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:07:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/nba/imma-just-rock-with-that-isaiah-thomas-goes-rogue-picks-former-celtics-player-over-current-star/", "title": "\"Imma Just Rock With That\": Isaiah Thomas Goes Rogue, Picks Former Celtics Player Over Current Star", "body": "Ahead of the 2024 NBA Finals, former Boston Celtics fan favorite Isaiah Thomas made a significant remark about former and current Celtics Kyrie Irving and Jayson Tatum.\n\nHe asserted that the Dallas Mavericks' Irving and Luka Doncic combo was better than Boston's Jaylen Brown and Tatum. In an interview with Rachel Nichols and DeMarcus Cousins on the Bully Ball podcast, Thomas was asked if he would place Kyrie Irving ahead of Tatum.\n\nThomas answered thus when Nichols asked whether he and Cousins would rank Irving ahead of Tatum: \"I am... Imma just rock with that.Jayson Tatum and those guys are really good. Jaylen Brown is really good. But Luka and Kyrie are something we haven't seen. And they have the best duo, like they don't just have the best player. I feel like they're the best duo. They just don't have the best team.\"\n\nAfter spending years with the Cavaliers, Kyrie Irving was moved to the Celtics for Isaiah Thomas, Jae Crowder, and Ante Zizic, in the 2018 first-round selection of the Brooklyn Nets.\n\nThomas also emphasized the uniqueness of the Irving-Doncic combination. He said it presents a basketball dynamic that has never been witnessed before. Before settling in Dallas, Irving and Thomas each made many trips across the league, with Thomas finding it challenging to get a job on an NBA franchise.\n\nAccording to the NBA, Jayson Tatum averaged 26.9 points, 8.1 rebounds, and 4.9 assists on 47.1% shooting. In the 2024 playoffs, he sustained this level of play, averaging 26.0 points, 10.4 rebounds, and 5.9 assists on 44.2% shooting.\n\nHowever, Kyrie Irving shot 41.1% from 3-point range and 49.7% from the field during the regular season, averaging 25.6 points, 5.2 assists, and 5.0 rebounds in 58 games.\n\nHe has been averaging 22.8 points, 5.2 assists, and 3.9 rebounds per game in the playoffs this year. Irving scored 21 points per game in his two regular-season meetings versus Tatum and the Celtics. Tatum averaged 35.5 points, 9.5 rebounds, and 4.0 assists in the Celtics' victories in both games versus the Mavericks.\n\nTatum has the most individual numbers, but Irving has more NBA Finals experience and a track record of winning. He has averaged 27.7 points, 4.2 assists, and 4.2 rebounds in 13 Finals games while playing.", "source": {"uri": "totalprosports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Total Pro Sports"}, "authors": helped him grow as a person.\n\nIrving was drafted into the NBA in 2011 and Bryant retired in 2016, with the pair facing against one another on six occasions.\n\nHe added that while Bryant is gone, the former Los Angeles Lakers legend \"walks with me in spirit\" every day.\n\n\"I feel his presence every day and I'm just grateful that I got a chance to get to know somebody like that, and I got a {"uri": "8162558050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "09:18:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T09:18:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T09:13:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/irving-is-healthier-happier/article_ba2a9b52-61e6-5c0c-b75f-c8a5e0ea4458.html", "title": "Irving is healthier, happier", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nNBA\n\nDALLAS -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago. It was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavs set to face the Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently, stopping short of mea culpas but making clear he's learned a lot along the way.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\nPeople are also reading... Names released in fatal motorcycle crash Deere to lay off global production, salaried employees at end of third quarter One killed, one injured in I-380 motorcycle accident Saturday night at Waterloo Waterloo man arrested in teen-enticing sting Reinbeck man detained after search turns up gun, cash, drugs UPDATE: Deere posts notice of 123 layoffs, 49 in Waterloo; global production, salaried employees cut Waterloo bicyclist suffers serious injuries after colliding with truck Waterloo council could turn old church into housing, day care Masic, Neff vie for Black Hawk County sheriff's position in Tuesday's primary election Man arrested for allegedly stealing Waterloo school district truck Iowa restaurant inspection update: Green slime, moldy meat, unlicensed eateries Fire destroys garage and vehicles in Waterloo Iowa Supreme Court overturns conviction in 2020 fatal shooting Part I: The Right Coach 12th Street housing development to be considered by Cedar Falls council\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player. Then came the COVID-19 pandemic and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play in home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, Irving asked out of Brooklyn, and he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavs point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. However, the duo's first full season together is exactly what the Mavs were expecting when they pulled off general manager Nico Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\n\"I'm enjoying every step of the way, Irving said. \"I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm enjoying the hot weather right now. I'm enjoying the Dallas community. We talked about this early in the season, just how much I felt embraced.\"\n\nCeltics' Brown, Tatum feel better equipped\n\nJaylen Brown has a $300 million contract, and Jayson Tatum is expected to get one, too.\n\nBut, neither player seems to care who's considered Boston's best player. And with the Celtics back in the NBA Finals for the second time in three years, they have another chance to finally win a ring that has alluded them.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason.\n\nBrown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\nNBA Finals\n\nBoston vs. Dallas\n\nThursday: at Boston, 7:30 p.m.\n\nSunday: at Boston, 7 p.m.\n\nWednesday: at Dallas, 7:30 p.m.\n\nJune 14: at Dallas, 7:30 p.m.\n\nx-June 17: at Boston, 7:30 p.m.\n\nx-June 20: at Dallas, 7:30 p.m.\n\nx-June 23: at Boston, 7 p.m.\n\nAll times Central Best-of-7; x-if necessary; TV: ABC\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I {"uri": "8165065787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:45:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:45:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:44:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://uproxx.com/dimemag/kyrie-irving-kristaps-porzingis-boston-dallas-failure-nba-finals/", "title": "Kyrie And Porzingis' Past Failures Led Them To The 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "The Boston Celtics held an event for fans at TD Garden on Oct. 4, 2018. At the time, Boston was the most exciting young team in the Eastern Conference, coming off a conference finals appearance that helped cement them as the next team in line if LeBron James ever decided to do something crazy, like join the Los Angeles Lakers in free agency.\n\nWhile Kyrie Irving couldn't play during that run -- which ended with a Game 7 loss at home to James and the Cleveland Cavaliers -- due to a knee injury, the All-Star guard was one of the stars on that Celtics team -- the guy Danny Ainge acquired in a trade with the Cavs the previous year to get them another championship. And in a moment in front of Boston's fans, Irving decided to express his intention to re-sign with the team instead of entering free agency the next summer.\n\nAnd then, Irving never signed a deal, and things deteriorated over what became his final year with the Celtics. You can pick from any number of moments where the vibes were just completely off, from the time Irving admitted that he called James and apologized for not realizing how hard being a leader is, to any of the comments to the media where Irving was just a little too blunt about, well, everything.\n\n\"It was just a chapter in my life that I got to enjoy for the most part,\" Irving told the media this week, per Tim MacMahon of ESPN. \"We had a great opportunity to do some special things, but it was cut short, just based off personal reasons on my end. One thing I look back on my time in Boston -- I've said this over the past few years, but somehow it gets tossed under the rug -- but the greatest thing I learned from Boston was just being able to manage not only my emotions or just what's going on on a day-to-day basis of being a leader of a team or being one of the leaders, and having young guys around you that have their own goals, but you have to learn how to put the big picture first.\"\n\nWhen free agency rolled around at the end of June in 2019, he decided to team up with Kevin Durant as a member of the Brooklyn Nets. It sent a shockwave throughout the league, largely because while the rumblings of Durant and Irving teaming up in the Big Apple weren't new, the expectation was that they'd head to Madison Square Garden and join the New York Knicks, instead.\n\nIt was quite the blow for the Knicks, which had just seen one of its hopeful building blocks leave town. Six months earlier, New York made the decision to trade Kristaps Porzingis to the Dallas Mavericks and end his tenure in New York after three and a half years -- reports indicated that a meeting between Porzingis and the Knicks led the team to believe he wanted a trade, as he had concerns about the direction of the franchise. What started as a promising marriage between a team desperate to get over the hump and a lottery pick whose skillset got him nicknamed \"The Unicorn\" devolved, and the Mavs were there to take advantage.\n\nBefore he ever got to play a game in a Dallas uniform, the team gave Porzingis a lucrative 5-year contract extension, as they finally got the running mate that would help Luka Doncic go from a budding superstar to an MVP with an All-Star sidekick. {"uri": "8162477530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "08:26:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T08:26:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T08:23:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/irving-is-healthier-happier/article_47a1397c-6b18-5681-89a8-6c0103ff6ac8.html", "title": "Irving is healthier, happier", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nNBA\n\nDALLAS -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago. It was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavs set to face the Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently, stopping short of mea culpas but making clear he's learned a lot along the way.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\nPeople are also reading... Little Chicago Deli reopens in Sioux City Friday Sioux City Marina operator responds to city's lawsuit SUX Pride creating a festive something for everybody event in Sioux City Woodbury County Court Report for May 28, 2024 Mary Jo (Sailors) McInnis East's Mackenzie Crawford is Broadway-bound for a chance at the Jimmys Athlete of the Week: A budding star emerging for SB-L in Moreau Fatal hit-and-run suspect returned to Sioux City, faces 4 charges Day-long, downtown event highlights 'So Much To Do' in Sioux City Boys state soccer: Heelan captures first state title with OT win over Assumption Nebraska baseball's NCAA tournament run continues after Huskers eliminate Niagara Parents of another Hinton wrestler sue coaches, school for alleged assaults Greenwell's attorney response to $53,000 fees in Gausman lawsuit, stating it should be halved Nelson, McNaughton seek Woodbury County Supervisors seat Woman believed to be dead turns out to be alive at Nebraska funeral home, officials say\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player. Then came the COVID-19 pandemic and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play in home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, Irving asked out of Brooklyn, and he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavs point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. However, the duo's first full season together is exactly what the Mavs were expecting when they pulled off general manager Nico Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\n\"I'm enjoying every step of the way, Irving said. \"I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm enjoying the hot weather right now. I'm enjoying the Dallas community. We talked about this early in the season, just how much I felt embraced.\"\n\nCeltics' Brown, Tatum feel better equipped\n\nJaylen Brown has a $300 million contract, and Jayson Tatum is expected to get one, too.\n\nBut, neither player seems to care who's considered Boston's best player. And with the Celtics back in the NBA Finals for the second time in three years, they have another chance to finally win a ring that has alluded them.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason.\n\nBrown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to The Dallas Mavericks guard, of course, has a history with the franchise and its fanbase.\n\nSince his departure in the summer of 2019, Irving has been the recipient of several not-so-warm welcomes back to TD Garden. Each time he's touched the ball, he's been met with a chorus of boos.\n\nAhead of Game 1, Irving was asked how he's handled the response from the Garden faithful.\n\n\"You just got to breathe through it,\" he told reporters at NBA Finals Media Day. \"To all my youngins out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions, what they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is. Don't overthink it.\"\n\nHis response is something that he feels he's been able to improve on, over the course of his many returns to Boston.\n\n\"Been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness. It could all be turned into a strength. There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball. The fans are going to say what they're going to say. I appreciate them and their relationship they have to the game. But it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nThe NBA Finals will mark Irving's third playoff series against the Celtics since he left for the Brooklyn Nets. {"uri": "8164813067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:56:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:56:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:55:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.businessupturn.com/trending/why-did-kyrie-irving-leave-the-celtics-revisiting-kyrie-irvings-decision-to-leave-celtics-for-nets/", "title": "Why did Kyrie Irving leave the Celtics? Revisiting Kyrie Irving's decision to leave Celtics for Nets | Business Upturn", "body": "You'd think Celtics fans had a front-row seat to a Greek tragedy every time Kyrie Irving touches the ball in the 2024 NBA Finals. Seriously, it's like witnessing a rollercoaster of emotions with every dribble.\n\nSure, it might seem like eons ago, but let's not forget, it's been a mere five seasons since Irving graced Boston's parquet floors.\n\nThe whole saga kicked off in 2017 with a blockbuster trade that saw Isaiah Thomas, a beloved figure in Celtics lore, shipped off to the Cavaliers in exchange for the enigmatic Irving. It was supposed to be the move that propelled the Celtics to championship glory, with Irving as the linchpin of a burgeoning super team. But alas, basketball, much like life, rarely goes according to script.\n\nInjuries, drama, and a dash of off-court antics quickly turned the Celtics' dream into a nightmare. Two seasons passed, marked by tantalizing glimpses of potential squandered in a sea of missed opportunities.\n\nThen came the fateful decision: Irving, amidst whispers of broken promises and shattered dreams, bid adieu to Boston in free agency. The parting left a bitter taste in the mouths of Celtics faithful, who had dared to hope for so much more.\n\nSo what led to the unraveling of this once-promising union? Well, grab some popcorn, because it's a tale as dramatic as any Shakespearean tragedy.\n\nInjuries hit the Celtics like a wrecking ball during Irving's inaugural season in Beantown. The heart-wrenching saga began with All-Star forward Gordon Hayward's catastrophic leg injury in the very first game. Just when you thought things couldn't get any worse, Irving himself went under the knife for a season-ending knee surgery barely a week before the playoffs.\n\nYet, against all odds, the Celtics battled their way to Game 7 of the 2018 Eastern Conference Finals, sans their two marquee players. It was a testament to the emerging talents of rookies like Jayson Tatum and sophomore standout Jaylen Brown, who began to showcase glimpses of their future stardom. But with newfound promise came a dilemma: too many mouths to feed on the scoring front, leading to a locker room rife with confusion.\n\nAs Irving entered the final year of his contract in the 2018-19 season, anticipation hung thick in the air. Despite opting against an early extension, he serenaded the TD Garden faithful with promises of loyalty during a preseason love-in.\n\n\"If you guys will have me back, I plan on re-signing here,\" Irving proclaimed to the adoring crowd, setting hopes soaring among Celtics die-hards.\n\nHe even went as far as envisioning his jersey hanging from the rafters, pledging allegiance to the city in a media t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate the next day. But alas, the season took an unforeseen turn, akin to a rollercoaster careening off its tracks.\n\nIrving's patience wore thin like an old sweater as frustrations mounted. He bemoaned the lack of veteran presence on the roster after a rocky start to the season, before unleashing a pointed tirade at the younger players in a memorable postgame presser.\n\nBy February, any semblance of a love affair with Boston had evaporated faster than snow in July. \"I'm going to do what's best for my career,\" declared Irving, the once-sainted star now unapologetically prioritizing personal ambition over team loyalty.\n\nWith a lackluster playoff performance culminating in a premature exit, the writing on the wall glowed with neon certainty: Irving's tenure in Boston was as good as over. He later attributed his tumultuous season to off-court distractions, including a family tragedy.\n\nBut forgiveness from Celtics fans? That seems about as likely as a snowball fight in July. The wounds of broken promises and dashed hopes run deep in the veins of Boston faithful, a stark reminder that in the NBA, loyalty can be as fleeting as a summer breeze.\n\nWell, it didn't take a hoops aficionado to see that Irving and the Celtics were about as compatible as oil and water after the 2019 NBA Playoffs.\n\nIn a move that surprised approximately zero people, the mercurial guard wasted no time in backtracking on his earlier pledges of eternal devotion to Boston. As soon as the free agency floodgates swung open, Irving swiftly inked a lucrative four-year, $141 million deal with the Brooklyn Nets, linking up with his buddy Kevin Durant to form a formidable dynamic duo.\n\nThe seismic shift in the NBA landscape was encapsulated in a single tweet from the oracle of basketball news himself, Adrian Wojnarowski, sending shockwaves through the league.\n\nIrving's tenure with the Nets lasted a respectable three and a half seasons before a change of scenery beckoned. In a deadline day stunner in 2023, he found himself donning the blue and white of the Mavericks, embarking on a new chapter in his enigmatic career. And so, the saga of Kyrie Irving continued, a tale as unpredictable and compelling as any in the annals of hoops lore.", "source": {"uri": "businessupturn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business {"uri": "8163702068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:45:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:45:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:24:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13499723/NBA-Finals-Notebook-Porzingis-Kyrie-LeBron-make-nice-Hardaway-Jr-throws-shade-dad.html", "title": "NBA Finals Notebook: Porzingis a go, Kyrie and LeBron make nice,...", "body": "BOSTON (AP) - Celtics 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis said he will be ready to \"just go out there and hoop\" for Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday night after missing Boston\u00b4s last 10 games with a strained left calf.\n\n\"It was a long road to get to this point for me. But feeling good,\" he said at media day on Wednesday. \"(It) burns inside of me, not being able to be out there. But tomorrow finally I\u00b4ll get the chance and I\u00b4m excited.\"\n\nPorzingis said he couldn\u00b4t predict how it will be once he gets into a game for the first time since April 29.\n\n\"I did as much as I could to prepare for this moment, but there\u00b4s nothing like game minutes and game experience that I\u00b4m going to get tomorrow,\" he said. \"It will be tough to jump into the finals like this.\"\n\nAn offseason acquisition that helped solidify the Celtics frontcourt, Porzingis averaged 20 points, 7.2 rebounds and almost two blocks per game. But he was again dogged by injuries that limited him to 57 games.\n\nHe left Game 4 of the first-round series against the Miami Heat and missed all of the next two rounds, when Boston eliminated Cleveland in five games and swept the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n\"Guys so far have been playing great, taking care of business, guys stepping up,\" he said, singling out Al Horford\u00b4s work at center in his absence. \"I just look forward to add more to complete the mission.\"\n\nKYRIE AND LEBRON\n\nLeBron James praised former teammate Kyrie Irving on a podcast, calling him \"the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nThe feeling is mutual.\n\n\"There\u00b4s a lot of gratitude there, as well,\" Irving said on Wednesday when asked if he had heard James\u00b4 comments. \"I think we both have been able to mature and really appreciate what we got a chance to accomplish.\"\n\nJames said on his podcast \"Mind the Game\" that he\u00b4s happy and proud to watch Irving in the finals, but at the same time he\u00b4s \"mad that I\u00b4m not his running mate anymore.\"\n\n\"There was nothing on a basketball floor that Kyrie couldn\u00b4t do,\" he said.\n\nIrving and James reached the finals three straight seasons with the Cavaliers, winning it all in 2016 and losing to the Warriors the following year. Then Irving requested a trade, and the relationship soured.\n\n\"I think there were some things that got in the way of our relationship when I was a little bit younger,\" Irving said at NBA Finals media day on Wednesday. \"Now that I\u00b4m able to vocalize how I feel as a man, be comfortable in it, stand on my square, my beliefs, where I\u00b4m coming from, I feel like our relationship\u00b4s different because of that now.\n\n\"(I) definitely miss him,\" Irving said. \"Just a mutual respect there for what we brought to the table. His leadership, my leadership style, I think it meshed very well. I was learning a lot from him that I\u00b4m appreciative for the rest of my life.\"\n\nIrving wound up in Boston, where he also had a still-festering fallout. In previous trips back to the Garden, he has been received rudely and a similar welcome is expected for Game 1 on Thursday night.\n\nTRASH-TALKING TIM\n\nTim Hardaway Jr. couldn\u00b4t resist the chance to talk trash about his father.\n\nAsked on Wednesday what it meant for him to be playing in the NBA Finals for the first time, Hardaway said, \"It means a lot. Especially being the first of my family to do so.\" Reporters chuckled and gasped.\n\nHardaway\u00b4s father was a five-time All-Star in 13 NBA seasons and was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2022. He finished in the top 10 of the NBA MVP voting three times, and also won a gold medal at the 2000 Olympics.\n\nBut he only made it as far as the conference finals once, losing with the Miami Heat to Michael Jordan\u00b4s Bulls in 1997.\n\nHardaway Jr. has never averaged 20 points in a season, like his father did five times, and his award votes have come mostly as a sixth man. But he said he had the advantage of his father\u00b4s experience.\n\n\"I wouldn\u00b4t get to this point without my dad,\" he said. \"He\u00b4s always by my side. He\u00b4s always a phone call away. He\u00b4s always supporting me, always coming to the games. He\u00b4s a phone call away when I\u00b4m struggling, when I\u00b4m not, even if I\u00b4m having great games in a stretch, he\u00b4s telling me to keep my head down, don\u00b4t stop, keep that energy, keep that flow going. And, he\u00b4s always reiterating to me: always have fun. He\u00b4s been telling me that since high school, and that\u00b4s what I\u00b4ve been trying to do my whole entire career.\n\n\"The guy has lived it and done it. So, you know, that\u00b4s that\u00b4s that\u00b4s the luxury I do have of having a father that played in this league.\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8161957323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "00:23:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T00:23:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T00:22:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://fanbuzz.com/nba/lebron-misses-playing-with-kyrie-irving-im-so-f-mad-im-not-his-running-mate-anymore/", "title": "LeBron Misses Playing With Kyrie Irving: 'I'm So F****** Mad I'm Not His Running Mate Anymore'", "body": "On Tuesday's episode of the Mind the Game Podcast with LeBron James and JJ Reddick, the topic of discussion was Kyrie Irving, who is set to make his fourth-ever NBA Finals appearance with the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nNotably, LeBron and Kyrie won a championship together while playing with the Cleveland Cavaliers during the 2015-16 season.\n\nIn every season James and Irving played with each other (2014-2017), they made a Finals appearance. Even so, many remember Kyrie requesting a trade after losing the 2017 Finals to the Warriors, as he seemingly didn't want to play second fiddle to LeBron anymore.\n\nNow LeBron finds himself reminiscing on the \"good old days\" that he had with his former partner in crime.\n\nEver since the two superstars broke up, the feelings of missing each other have been mutual, as Kyrie reportedly regretted forcing himself out of Cleveland after he found that the grass wasn't greener on the other side.\n\n\"We definitely would've won more championships... Me and him [LeBron] in the league together running Cleveland, and then being able to put a better team together every single year would've definitely been worth it.\" Kyrie said.\n\nThat is to say, last season LeBron and the Los Angeles Lakers sought to acquire Kyrie ahead of the trade deadline, before the Brooklyn Nets ultimately sent him to the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nLeBron really wanted to reunite with his former teammate as he referenced this in an ESPN interview at the time.\n\n\"I can't sit here and say I'm not disappointed on not being able to land such a talent, but someone that I had great chemistry with, and know I got great chemistry with on the floor, that can help you win championships, in my mind, in my eyes.\"\n\nNow fast forward a year later, and the sentiment regarding Kyrie is much the same for LeBron.\n\n\"Dallas may be able to not only win the Western Conference finals, they might be able to win the whole thing,\" James stated. \"Because of that [Irving being a] wild card. ... He's the most gifted player the NBA has ever seen.\"\n\nAfter calling Kyrie \"a wizard,\" LeBron said, \"There was nothing on the basketball floor that Kyrie couldn't do.\" LeBron noted that he was happy for Kyrie, who has now made it the Finals without himself this time; however, be that as it may, Kyrie will always be missed.\n\n\"I'm so f****** mad at the same time that I'm not his running mate anymore.\"\n\nAll that is left is the memory of playing with each other. With this in mind, during the 2016 NBA Finals, LeBron and Kyrie both helped lead the Cavs back from a 3-1 deficit. In particular in Game 5, both co-stars scored 41 points a piece, and this was the first time in NBA history that two teammates scored 40+ in the same Finals game.\n\nThen during Game 7 the tandem contributed two of the most memorable moments, which were known as \"the block\" and the \"shot.\"\n\nAfter LeBron blocked Andre Iguodala's shot to keep the game tied at 89-89, Kyrie hit a step back three-pointer to help lift the Cavs over the Warriors to bring the city of Cleveland their first sports franchise championship since 1964 (ending 52-year drought).\n\nKyrie will face his former team, {"uri": "2024-06-377631114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:25:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:25:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:00:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/mavericks-news-kyrie-irving-kobe-bryant-nba-finals", "title": "Mavericks' Kyrie Irving reveals Kobe Bryant's 'superpowers' inspiration before NBA Finals", "body": "\"I don't know if anyone in here has ever lost a mentor or lost someone that's a little bit older than them, meant something to them,\" Irving said. \"Even if you guys don't talk everyday, there was still that connection that they were always gonna be there for you. It wasn't just him (Bryant), it was his family as well. They supported me unconditionally. I miss him every single day alongside the rest of the world and all the Kobe supporters around the world.\"\n\nBryant has impacted no shortage of people around the world regardless of whether or not they play basketball. He was a role model who many people looked up to. Bryant's legacy has led to further inspiration to this day.\n\nKyrie Irving clearly misses the NBA Hall of Famer. However, he is still using the lessons that Bryant taught him as the Mavericks prepare for the NBA Finals.\n\nKobe Bryant's \"superpowers\"\n\nIrving further explained how Bryant left an impact both on and off the floor.\n\n\"He held such a big presence,\" Irving continued. \"He knew what his power was. He knew what his superpowers were. And they weren't on the court every time. They were his ability to approach life, how he inspired you to continue to do extra even when you got tired. I think his life lesson has transcended basketball or any sport or any entertainment business... That's what I felt like he was teaching me, to be able to carry the torch and also know how to pass it along.\n\n\"Obviously along that journey he's won a few championships that I'm still enamored with, still chasing to a certain degree. I do want to be able to sit at that table to say that I have multiple championships and I'm a multiple champion in the best league in the world.\"\n\nKyrie Irving has plans on winning more championships. He's four victories away from becoming a multi-time champion. And there is no question that Kobe played a role in his NBA journey.\n\nKyrie Irving: \"I feel his presence everyday\"\n\nThe entire world misses Kobe Bryant. Bryant's fearless mindset made him well-respected around the league.\n\n\"He always reminds me to enjoy the journey,\" Irving said. \"The journey is the reward. Put it in perspective. There are billions of people who are gonna love you. There are billions of people that are not going to love you. I think you should make the right choice... and go with the people that support you through and through. Make them proud, make yourself proud. Everyday he walks with me in spirit. I feel his presence everyday. I'm just grateful that I got a chance to know somebody like that and I got a chance to challenge somebody like that to one-on-one... Just understanding that there are bigger things than just the game of basketball like woman empowerment.\n\n\"But also doing the little things that people don't see, meaning helping the world selflessly. I could go on and on about this, but he helped out a lot of people that no one really knows about. He did things without anyone's praise. I try to follow in that same lineage and create my own path, create my own formula to success while also commemorating his formula that he gave me.\"", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", {"uri": "8162537346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "09:06:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T09:06:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T09:02:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/irving-is-healthier-happier/article_61dccdf3-562f-55bc-be14-e044c0449a11.html", "title": "Irving is healthier, happier", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nNBA\n\nDALLAS -- Kyrie Irving directed obscene gestures and profanity at a hostile crowd in Boston the last time the star Dallas guard saw the Celtics, one of his former teams, in the playoffs two years ago. It was one tumultuous moment of many in a tension-filled tenure with Brooklyn that ended with his trade to the Mavericks about 10 months later.\n\nHealthier and happier, as he likes to say, Irving is back on the biggest stage in his sport with the Mavs set to face the Celtics in the NBA Finals starting Thursday.\n\nThroughout the deepest playoff run for Dallas in 13 years, the reflective side of Irving has surfaced frequently, stopping short of mea culpas but making clear he's learned a lot along the way.\n\n\"I will say last time in Boston, I don't think that was the best -- not this regular season, but when we played in the playoffs and everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (stuff) a little bit -- that wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level,\" Irving said.\n\nPeople are also reading... Complaint: Stolen debit card used to make fraudulent purchases in La Crosse Biker suffers injuries in fall on Grandad Bluff in La Crosse Father of Baraboo High School graduate blocks superintendent from shaking daughter's hand THE WAY IT WAS: Myrick Park Zoo, 3 June 2004 Play Grounds of La Crosse set to open largest indoor playground in Wisconsin in November Exotic dance club in Monroe County destroyed by fire Steve Cahalan: Fat Pat's Brewery opens in downtown Spring Grove La Crosse board denies marshland-specific camping ban Structure fire in Onalaska causes major damage to building Steve Cahalan: Trading card store opens in Valley View Mall High school cross country: Onalaska senior makes college decision Police reportedly uncover substantial drug stash in La Crosse traffic stop UPDATE: 36-year-old Ettrick man identified as victim of Trempealeau County homicide WIAA state track and field notebook: La Crosse Logan's Julie Yang caps career with three medals WIAA state track and field: Onalaska wins Division 1 boys 3,200 relay\n\n\"It wasn't a great reflection on my end towards the next generation on what it means to control your emotions in that type of environment, no matter what people are yelling at you.\"\n\nBefore jilting Boston fans by signing with the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019, Irving was already a polarizing player. Then came the COVID-19 pandemic and Irving's refusal to get vaccinated, which meant he couldn't play in home games for Brooklyn because of New York City's vaccine mandate for employees.\n\nNext was Irving's social media post of a link to a movie containing antisemitic material, which led to a suspension from the Nets and the end of his longtime business relationship with Nike.\n\nUltimately, Irving asked out of Brooklyn, and he and Durant were traded days apart last year, giving Irving a new co-star in Mavs point guard Luka Doncic.\n\nThe partial season together didn't work out for Irving and Doncic. Dallas missed the playoffs. However, the duo's first full season together is exactly what the Mavs were expecting when they pulled off general manager Nico Harrison's first blockbuster trade.\n\n\"I'm enjoying every step of the way, Irving said. \"I'm not taking anything for granted. I'm enjoying the hot weather right now. I'm enjoying the Dallas community. We talked about this early in the season, just how much I felt embraced.\"\n\nCeltics' Brown, Tatum feel better equipped\n\nJaylen Brown has a $300 million contract, and Jayson Tatum is expected to get one, too.\n\nBut, neither player seems to care who's considered Boston's best player. And with the Celtics back in the NBA Finals for the second time in three years, they have another chance to finally win a ring that has alluded them.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason.\n\nBrown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dallas Mavericks Boston {"uri": "2024-06-380685104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:04:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://jamaica-star.com/article/sports/20240606/celtics-seek-redemption-nba-finals", "title": "Celtics seek redemption in NBA Finals", "body": "As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinised stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realised that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. {"uri": "2024-06-380240793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "01:01:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T01:01:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:42:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/mavericks-news-kyrie-irving-drops-huge-hint-future-alongside-luka-doncic", "title": "Mavericks' Kyrie Irving drops huge hint at future alongside Luka Doncic", "body": "Fit was a big reason why a lot of avid spectators did not think the Dallas Mavericks would be here. For one, Kyrie Irving was in search of a team where he could lead to glory as the number one option. Another concern was that Luka Doncic was also fairly ball-dominant. A missed postseason and some adjustments from Jason Kidd later, they are four wins against the Boston Celtics away from getting another taste at the Larry O'Brien trophy.\n\nAll of those woes that were hurled at the Mavericks seemed to have dissipated. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving seemed to now take turns playing the role of tormentor against the teams that they have faced. A stacked Los Angeles Clippers squad, an energetic Oklahoma City Thunder, and a hyped-up Minnesota Timberwolves team all had to learn the same lesson. The two have surely thrived with Jason Kidd. So, the next question after this Celtics series is: will these two stay together for a long time?\n\nKyrie Irving had the answer and it sounded like a different than what he gave in front of the Celtics faithful a few years back, via SportsCenter on ESPN.\n\n\"The future is still being written. But I can tell you that with all the extensions that are going around with J. Kidd and Nico. Potentially, with Luka this summer too. I don't mind being complimentary if we're gonna continue to put this band together,\" the master of ball-handling said.\n\nUncertainty with the Mavericks\n\nIrving is not locking anything in at all. He knows that there is a lot in store for him after this postseason with the Mavericks whether they win it all or not. At the end of the day, he is choosing to focus on what is in front of them and that is this NBA Finals matchup with the Celtics.\n\n\"We have some great pieces around us. There's always those thoughts that could creep in. Those 'what-ifs' and 'what could happen.' You never know from season to season. I just like to let it play out and stay in the present moment. I am enjoying my time here and I've enjoyed my time here,\" Irving concluded.\n\nNico Harrison has already inked a deal with the Mavericks days before the finals. Now, it will just be a matter of getting both Jason Kidd and Irving to stay. They could run it back with a relatively young squad and just move around some pieces to stay competitive.\n\nAfter all, Irving is averaging 25.6 points on a 49.7% clip from all three levels of scoring. He also helps Luka Doncic facilitate such that they get the offense going. His effort in creating opportunities for his teammates has netted the Mavericks an average of 5.2 assists. Moreover, his defensive acumen has been great whether he is on the ball-handler or anticipating bad passes in lanes. This has gotten him 1.3 steals.\n\nThe numbers and fit are there. All the Mavericks have to do is convince him to stay and have a happy environment around him.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8163802568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "01:36:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T01:36:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T01:35:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/06/05/sports/kyrie-irvings-plan-for-vitriolic-celtics-fan-breathe-through-it/", "title": "Kyrie Irving plans to 'breathe through' Celtics fans' vitriol at NBA...", "body": "BOSTON -- Clearly at a better place with his game and comfort than those disastrous seasons in Brooklyn, Kyrie Irving says he'll have a meditative approach to the hostility that awaits from the Celtics crowd in Thursday's Game 1 of the Finals.\n\n\"You just got to breathe through it,\" Irving said. \"To all the [younger players] out there that are dealing with some of the crowd reactions, what they're saying to you, you have to breathe, realize that is not as hostile as you think it is. Don't overthink it.\"\n\nIt was different during those Nets seasons, which immediately followed Irving ditching Boston in free agency.\n\nBack then, Irving provoked the Beantown crowd by stepping on the midcourt leprechaun, lighting sage around the sidelines, throwing up a middle finger at a fan and suggesting Boston's racism as a factor.\n\nTime may have softened some of the anger, but there's little doubt Irving will be Public Enemy No. 1 at TD Garden.\n\nHe plans to weaponize the vitriol.\n\n\"Been able to work through that and understand that some of that is anxiety, some of that is nervousness. It could all be turned into a strength,\" Irving said. \"There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball. The fans are going to say what they're going to say. I appreciate them and their relationship they have to the game. But it's about the players at the end of the day.\"\n\nBoston is among the most hostile NBA arenas with a long history of making the opposition uncomfortable.\n\nOne Celtics fan, Cole Buckley, hurled a water bottle at Irving during a game in 2021.\n\nHe was arrested.\n\nCurrent Mavericks coach Jason Kidd once said his family was being harassed by Celtics fans during the 2002 Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nBack then, Kidd was the star point guard for the New Jersey Nets and was the target of \"wife beater\" chants during the game.\n\nHis young son, TJ, and wife at the time, Joumana, were heckled in their arena seats.\n\n\"It bothers me. I can't protect them,\" Kidd said in 2002. \"I'm worried about them at the same time I'm worried about trying to win a ballgame.\n\n\"You can't do that to somebody's family, put them in jeopardy for their safety. They came there to enjoy the game just like [Celtics fans] did.\"\n\nLuka Doncic is also anticipating an enthusiastic crowd.\n\n\"It's very loud crowd. Everybody knows that. They've been known for that,\" Doncic said \"It's hard to play in this place. The crowd is amazing for their team. All I got to say is we got to stay together. It's us against them.\"", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrie_Irving", "type": {"uri": "8162655616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "10:12:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T10:12:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T10:11:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/05/sports/celtics-mavericks-nba-finals/", "title": "Having the Celtics back in the Finals is good for us and good for the NBA - The Boston Globe", "body": "Like the New York Yankees, the Green Bay Packers, and the Montreal Canadiens, the Celtics are synonymous with their sport. In the second half of the 20th century, when the fledgling NBA was coming of age, Bill Russell, Bob Cousy, and Red Auerbach put Boston's parquet floor on the national sports map, winning 11 championships in 13 seasons.\n\nIn subsequent decades, as the torch was passed from Russell and Sam Jones to men named Havlicek, Cowens, Maxwell, Bird, Parish, and McHale, the Celtics continued winning championships -- two in the 1970s and three more in the golden '80s. It was also in the '80s that Larry Bird and Magic Johnson teamed with Michael Jordan and commissioner David Stern to make the NBA a global entertainment entity.\n\nWhile notions of Celtic Pride and Garden Mystique have largely endured, the franchise's stretch of championship regularity stopped after Bird & Co. won their final crown on June 8, 1986.\n\nSince that day, while NBA mini-dynasties thrived then died in Los Angeles (17 total championships, same as Boston), Chicago, San Antonio, and the Bay Area, the Celtics have won only one banner -- in 2007-08 when Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce, and Ray Allen crushed the Lakers in six games.\n\nNow the Celtics are favorites to win again.\n\nCoached by 35-year-old Joe Mazzulla, the Celtics won a league-best 64 games this season and are 12-2 in the playoffs, methodically toppling tomato cans from Miami, Cleveland, and Indiana. The Celtics are talented, deep, rested, and prepared for the return of starting center Kristaps Porzingis (calf), who hasn't played since April 29. Just about everyone outside of the Dallas-Fort Worth region is picking Boston to win.\n\nTatum and Brown, superstars drafted by Danny Ainge (who learned at the foot of Auerbach), are in their seventh season together and will be playing in their second Finals. Two years ago, the Celtics led the Warriors, two games to one, before dropping the final three games to Steph Curry, Draymond Green & Co.\n\n\"We can learn from that experience being in the Finals,\" Tatum said last weekend. \"This go-around is a lot different. Obviously we've been there before, we came up short. It's a great opportunity to make it to the Finals again. You don't always get a second chance.\"\n\nThe Celtics also feature guards Jrue Holiday (who won a ring with the Bucks) and Derrick White, a pair of terrific acquisitions by president of basketball operations Brad Stevens. And let's not forget 38-year-old Al Horford, who has played in 181 career playoff games and is overdue for his first ring.\n\nThe Mavericks are a 5-seed who won only 50 regular-season games and lost two of two against Boston (the Celtics beat them by 28 in March). Dallas made some midseason trades and went 16-4 in its final 20 games, then 12-5 in the playoffs. The Mavericks' best player is 25-year-old Doncic, a Bird clone from Slovenia, guaranteed to entertain and likely to win at least one game all by himself.\n\nThe Mavericks also have Irving, the capo di tutti capi of Boston sports villains. One of the most talented all-purpose guards in NBA history (don't forget that he won a championship with LeBron James in Cleveland), Irving played only two seasons (2017-19) for the Celtics, yet managed to offend more Hub sports patrons than Bill Laimbeer, Ulf Samuelsson, and Alex Rodriguez combined.\n\nBoston fans' hatred for Irving is seemingly boundless. Bad blood was first spilled when Kyrie reneged on a pledge to re-sign with the Celtics on the eve of his second season in Green (\"I wasn't my best self,\" Irving acknowledged Monday). This triggered five years of dueling insults between Irving and New England sports fans.\n\nIn 2020, then a member of the Brooklyn Nets, Irving burned sage around the parquet floor before a regular-season game. Later that season, in a series in which the Nets eliminated the Celtics from the playoffs, Irving stomped on the Celtics' sacred midcourt logo, then was the target of a water bottle hurled from the stands. This led to Irving's charge of \"underlying racism and just treating people like they're in a human zoo.\"\n\nOne year later, Kyrie compared Boston fans to a \"scorned girlfriend,\" then flipped off the Garden crowd in the middle of a playoff joust. A few months after that, Irving offended all of humanity, retweeting an antisemitic social media post, which resulted in him getting suspended by his own team (Brooklyn's front office stated that Irving was \"unfit to be associated with the Nets\").\n\nIrving effectively set fire to the Nets' Dream Team he'd assembled (including Kevin Durant and James Harden), missed a bunch of games because he refused to get a COVID vaccination, and was eventually traded to Dallas. He has been a model citizen for Jason Kidd's Mavericks, who've won one championship (2011) in their 44-year history.\n\nThere's a playoff push to anoint Kyrie and Luka as the NBA's best backcourt of all time.\n\nThis makes for interesting debate.\n\nWarriors fans like Curry and Klay Thompson, while folks in LA can make a case for Magic Johnson and Byron Scott, or Jerry West and Gail Goodrich. Michael Jordan and Ron Harper were pretty good for the Bulls.\n\nNaturally, the Celtics have candidates. John Havlicek occasionally paired in the backcourt with Jo Jo White. Dennis Johnson and Ainge won two championships together. Ray Allen and Rajon Rondo were a good combo for a couple of seasons.\n\nGoing back further, Auerbach had four Hall of Fame guards on the same championship team for three full seasons from 1958-61. Cousy and Sam Jones, who played six seasons together, combined to win 16 rings.\n\nCousy's jersey No. 14 and Sam's No. 24 will be hanging high above courtside when the Celtics and Mavericks get started Thursday night.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Russell", {"uri": "8162801870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "11:40:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T11:40:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T11:39:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/report-nets-were-offered-russell-113044391.html", "title": "Report: Nets were offered Russell Westbrook, picks for Kyrie Irving", "body": "The Brooklyn Nets are home for the summer after missing the chance to participate in the postseason in any capacity after their disappointing performance in the 2023-24 season. As Brooklyn, along with the rest of the NBA world, watches former Net Kyrie Irving try to win the 2024 NBA Finals, a new report has surfaced.\n\nPer Dave McMenamin of ESPN, the Nets received an interesting trade offer from the Los Angeles Lakers for Irving when the relationship between him and Brooklyn broke down close to the trade deadline of the 2022-23 campaign. According to what his sources told McMenamin, the Lakers offered Russell Westbrook along with first-round picks in 2027 and 2029.\n\nAt the time, the Nets were trying to negotiate a contract extension with Irving given that he was in the final year of his deal. Brooklyn wanted to retain Irving to a long-term deal that Irving wanted, but only if the contract had certain stipulations tied to how much time Irving missed.\n\nIrving did not want his contract to have any stipulations in it and when both sides couldn't come to an agreement, he requested a trade on Feb. 3 of last season and was traded to the Dallas Mavericks less than two days later. Reports at the time suggested that Irving's preferred destination was the Lakers so that he could reunite with LeBron James, but ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported shortly after the trade that Brooklyn preferred what Dallas had to offer.\n\nOn Feb. 5, 2023, the Nets traded Irving and Markieff Morris to the Mavericks for Spencer Dinwiddie, Dorian Finney-Smith, a 2029 unprotected first-round pick, and second-round picks in 2027 and 2029. One can wonder if the Lakers' first-round picks in 2027 and 2029 would be more valuable than Dallas' first-round pick in 2029, but that would have required Brooklyn to re-route Westbrook, whom the {"uri": "2024-06-379818612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:12:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:12:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:50:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/mavericks-fatal-flaw-that-will-doom-them-vs-celtics-2024-nba-finals", "title": "Mavericks' fatal flaw that will doom them vs. Celtics in 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "The Dallas Mavericks toppled three of the top four seeds in the Western Conference en route to the 2024 NBA Finals. Luka Doncic has been the best player in the 2024 NBA Playoffs, and that must continue being the case if they want to capture their first crown since 2011. Kyrie Irving has been phenomenal for Dallas after they snagged him from the Brooklyn Nets before last year's trade deadline.\n\nIt is just not the two doing the majority of the work as trade deadline acquisitions P.J. Washington and Daniel Gafford have been incredible for head coach Jason Kidd. Other organizations could have been more aggressive in acquiring these two big men, but the Mavericks took a leap of faith and now these two assets are vital cogs in their quest for an NBA Championship.\n\nThe positive remarks have been overflowing from the media and supporters about the campaign of the Mavericks as they were barely any pundits predicting them to make the finals in the preseason. Even with the plethora of fans cheering for the underdog, there is one particular fatal flaw that can hinder their championship run.\n\n*Watch NBA games LIVE with fuboTV (click for a free trial)*\n\nInability to maximize the strength of their role players\n\nFor any individual previewing this finals series, it has been constantly mentioned that the Boston Celtics are the more talented unit. They have the best top-six in the association, but one can argue that the Mavericks have the two best players in this series. Doncic and Irving have been sensational in this postseason, and both guys have proven to not fold under the pressure of playing in the NBA Finals.\n\nDoncic will still get his usual numbers in almost every outing, but there is a legitimate belief Irving can be limited scoring-wise. Irving struggled in both contests against the Celtics because they have the size to combat his strengths. Thus when Irving cannot find his rhythm, the Mavericks will search for the explosion of some role players, such as Washington, Gafford, or Derrick Lively.\n\nWith the Celtics playing a five-out style, the strategy of having Gafford or Lively patrol the paint in every possession of the game may not be effective because Kristaps Porzingis and Al Horford can shoot the three-ball with high efficiency. Moreover, the Mavericks bigs cannot hide on any of the Celtics wings because of their outstanding scoring prowess.\n\nThere could be instances wherein Washington and Maxi Kleber will be utilized in the Dallas frontcourt because of the versatility of the Celtics' bigs. Moreover, Washington's main contributions will be on his outside shooting accuracy so if he cannot find the mark from long distance, his threat on the floor will be slightly diminished.\n\nSimilar to Washington, the Mavericks' fifth starter Derrick Jones Jr. is not comfortable dribbling too many times in a possession so if the Celtics force them to attack on their own, that would spell trouble for the Mavericks. Boston is far more formidable than their last three opponents, so Dallas must be ready for their weaknesses to be exposed and find constant ways to counter it with brilliant adjustments.\n\nMentioning a bevy of ways to counter the power of the Mavericks' role players will put too much pressure on Doncic and Irving. Thus, the Mavericks must not fall into the trap of overly relying on Doncic and Irving to send them to the Promised Land.
